name: Jito
description:
From the designer notes: "JITO is a multi-game format rather than a single game. It can be simply competative, like most games. It can be a sophisticated game that features competitive cooperation, or it can be a completely cooperative game. You are invited to invent your own game using the board, but we would suggest that you start with the usual competitive game to learn how to balance cards most effectively and how to guess future peg locations with the greatest success. (Remember that the longest dimension of a card is from one corner to another.)"

In Game I., 2 players (or 2 teams of 2 players) compete to be the first the cross the board from one site to the opposite side with a continuous bridge of cards balanced on pegs.

Play progresses by each player throwing 2,d6 dice then a player may place a peg in the area on the board that matches the number thrown. After placing a peg, you may attempt to balance one or more cards on your peg(s). You may not overlap or touch an opponent's card bridge or share pegs. You must place a card within 20 seconds or lose your turn. The game ends when one of the players spans the board from one side to the opposite side (side to side, up and down, or diagonally). A completed bridge is worth 3 points. The usual match is to 6, 9, or 12 points.

Game II variant: This variant is a cooperative/competitive game for 3 players. Three players attempt to cross the board, but at any time 2 players may voluntarily decide to merge and build a bridge together. If they succeed in reaching the opposite site first, each player receives 1.5 points. The usual match is to 4, 5, or 7 points.

Game III variant: This version is fully cooperative and is for 2, 3, or, 4 players. All players work together to build a successful bridge. Individual scoring is assessed by counting the same-colored number of cards belonging to an individual player. You may also desire to set a time limit as the goal for building a bridge together.

name: Cat Hiding Plus
description: The expansion pack Cat Hiding Plus adds four different types of cards to either Cat Hiding or Cat Hiding DX, with these cards being played from the hand to peek at two cat cards in play or swap one goal for another.
categories: Animals, Children's Game, Expansion for Base-game

name: Neuestes Post- u. Reisespiel
description:
Objective: Be the first reaching space 45
- moving by turns -
Simple 'Roll&Move' game; each space you land on has printed instructions you have to follow immidiately like: step forward or backwards, pay or get...; space 45 must be reached precisely;
note:
Game should had been published early 1900 (indicated by drawings and numbering system); publisher was well known by term/products: 'Neuruppiner Bilderbogen' (pictorial broadsheet)

name: Frankfurter Umwelt-Spiel
description:
Objective: Be the first making a complete circuit around the board
- acting/moving by turns -
Each player moves forward according die roll; draw a card and follow instructions, often finding correct answer. Question & answer cards focus on enviromental issues.
categories: Children's Game, Dice, Educational, Environmental, Trivia

name: Wissens-Quiz für Kinder: Tiere, Technik, Natur
description:
This learning/quiz game follows the usual scheme for quiz and trivia games: One stops his move on a colored spot and has to answer a question from that category. If the answer is correct, the player receives a knowledge chip in that color. The first player who has 8 chips in different colors, wins the game.

This is a 3-in-1 edition with more than 3,000 questions (as opposed to the 1,000 in the separate editions) about

Tiere (Animals): Pets/Local Animals - Exotic Animals - Reptiles - Animals in and around Water - Birds - Insects - Prehestoric Animals - Animals in Books and Films

Technik (Technology): Cars - Motorbikes - Aeroplanes - Ships - Railways - Space Flight - Computer & Internet - Technology in General

Natur (Nature): Trees - Shrubs - Mushrooms - Flowers - Garden and Agriculture - Heaven & Earth - Environment and nature protection - Nature in general

name: Wettrennen mit dem Verderb
description:
Objective: be the first reaching space 80/learn more about the lifecycle of food
- moving by turns -
Move forward according die roll; ending on a marked space follow instructions printed on the back of the map

name: Mecha Mettle
description:
Theme
In the distant future, the galaxy is at war. Battle rages across the stars as campaigns are won and lost in the vastness of space. Your role in this conflict puts you as the captain in command of a customized ship, whose purpose is to engage your enemies in thrilling and strategic space combat. Successful command requires you to know how to use your ship to its fullest. Attacking with your modules, evading incoming assaults, and maintaining the ship’s integrity is all done with the end goal of taking advantage of weaknesses in your enemy’s defense. Be strong, be brave, and most importantly, take risks.

Overview
Mecha Mettle is a 2 player card and dice game where the players are engaged in space combat as captains of their own custom ships. Players build their ship by playing module cards and choosing components that give special ship abilities. Battle takes place by firing with modules and rolling dice to resolve combat. Positioning and taking advantage of better numbers is the key to winning. The game ends once one player destroys 5 of their opponents ports.
categories: Card Game, Dice, Print & Play, Space Exploration
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Player Elimination, Take That, Variable Player Powers

name: The Great Depression: The New Deal
description:
You are a governor of a state hard hit by the depression in the United States during the 1930s. You must work to implement new deal programs started by the Roosevelt administration. Achieve victory by building major civil works such as the Hoover Dam and the Triborough bridge. Each game, the goals are slightly different, but players compete to build infrastructure, raise their income, raise the morale of their people, and the player with the most victory points at the end of the game wins.

Players are given a player board at the beginning of the game and you raise your income by buying program cards and taking on debt to help increase the morale of your people. You can build programs such as the civilian conservation corps and the civil works administration. Each card gives you benefits in terms of job creation, income increases, and increases (or sometimes decreases) in happiness. Players have to choose between opening up more programs or using their money to decrease their debt and build large public works projects which give victory points at the end of the game. Sometimes borrowing large sums of money pays off and sometimes it lands you in the poor house.

name: Who's the Skipper?
description:
From the publisher's Web site:

Developed for Both Power and Sailboaters... "Who's The Skipper" is mobile fun for boaters of all ages ... unique game design combines luck, strategy and boating knowledge enabling novice to compete with even the most experienced avid seaman.

A Boater's Game... built on 500 basic to in-depth "Nauti-Bender" questions, designed to determine Who's The Skipper! Boat handling... docking... navigation... these are just some of the seamanship topics waiting to challenge you. Plus, keep a sharp lookout for those beguiling "Murphy Cards" that will have everyone in "knots"... and may turn even the saltiest "Captain" into a galley slave!

Whether you're in the cockpit, dockside or by the fireplace... whether you're a novice, intermediate or experienced yachtsman... or whether it's a boating day or not... you can be at the helm with Who's The Skipper, an enjoyable and fun way to learn (or reinforce) your sailing and seamanship skills!
categories: Card Game, Educational, Nautical, Party Game, Trivia

name: Vile Consequences
description:
A bad taste card game where players compete to make sentences out of the words they have been dealt. The players then vote on the best sentence, with that player scoring a point.

This game could be described as a cross between Mad Libs, Consequences and Cards Against Humanity.

Vile Consequences includes 107 cards with 4 word sentence pieces on each card.

name: Dungeon Crawl
description:
Inspired by classic RPGs, Dungeon Crawl is a game that challenges you to explore dungeons, collect loot, and backstab your friends.

Strap on your sword, grab your spellbook, and dive into the role of a dungeon delving adventurer! Be an axe wielding barbarian, a spell slinging sorceress, or divinely protected priest and battle monsters, survive traps, and talk your way past the guards to obtain their treasures. When things get tough, team up with a friend, but only until they outlive their usefulness, because there can be only one winner in Dungeon Crawl!

How it is played:

Players choose one of 10 unique, fantasy-archetypical characters (fighter, priest, rogue, sorceress, etc.), each with different stats and powers. They then move from town to different randomly generated locations where they have to complete combat, skill, and trap encounters to earn loot and experience points.

The random and modular nature of the game means that there are over 15 billion combinations in which encounters and locations can occur.

Players can team up to form parties, making it easier to complete encounters, but splitting the rewards with their group, or go solo where things are harder, but they get 100% of the rewards. They may also use bonus tokens gained from successfully completing encounters to aid themselves or hinder their opponents.

The game ends when the first level 5 dungeon is completed, and the player with the most experience points when the game ends is the winner.
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Modular Board, Variable Player Powers

name: Der Flug ins Weltall
description:
Objective: Be the first reaching target zone
- moving by turns -
Simple 'Roll&Move' game with scientific and utopian subjects. Ending on a numbered/marked space follow instructions glued into the lid,
categories: Children's Game, Dice, Educational, Racing, Space Exploration

name: Kjenn Ditt Fedreland
description:
Kjenn Ditt Fedreland ("Know Your Fatherland" or "Know Your Homeland") is a quiz game about Norwegian geography.
One person leads the game, having the list of correct answers in front of him. The other players have each one board with a part of a map of Norway. On the boards there are spots with numbers 1 to 90.
Number tokens are drawn randomly, and if a player has that number on his board and is able to tell the name of that place, he can put the token on that spot. First to fill all his spots is the winner.

Contents:
6 player cardboard boards
90 round cardboard tokens, numbered 1-90
1 list of geographical names
1 rules sheet

name: Sesam
description:
Full name of the game is: Sesam Grammatikkspill - Ali Baba åpner døren til hulen ("Sesam Grammar Game - Ali Baba opens up the cave door"). This is a flexible ruled grammar (educational) quiz game.
There are 56 assignments. In the first 28 assignments (each containing 21-28 words/word spaces) your task is to categorize words in their correct word classes. The last 28 assignments (each containing 2-10 sentences) you need to define each word's correct grammar name in the sentence. The answer is given by taking tokens, like for instance "conjuction" and "preposition" (black) or "object" and predicate" (red) and put them on the word space. For each correct answer you gain 2 points.

The idea of the game is teaching and testing grammar skills, and was encouraged for use in schools.

Contents:
14 cardboard boards with 56 assignments
Cardboard word class tokens
Box inserts for word class tokens
1 booklet with rules and answers.

name: Cache-cache Souris
description: In Cache-cache Souris ("Hide and Seek Mouse"), one player or team wants to move the cat Felix to catch the mouse Souricette, while the mouse player wants to keep it safe. They take turns placing cards on the playing area, gradually forming a labyrinth that sometimes opens a passage between the animals and sometimes throws an obstacle — a house, a cow, a scarecrow — onto the path. Will Felix find a way to the mouse? Will Souricette manage to hide until Felix tires out?

name: Spot 'n Learn
description:
Compilation includes three full versions of Spot it! packaged in a box, with each game in its own tin.

Spot it! is a simple pattern recognition game in which players try to find an image shown on two cards.

Games included:

- Spot it! Alphabet
- Spot it! Numbers & Shapes
- Spot it! Basic English

Packaging describes target age as 3-6. The first two titles are ages 3+; however, Spot it! Basic English is ages 6+ and requires reading ability.

name: Unter blauen Fahnen ziehn wir mit "Frösi" durch Berlin!
description:
Objective: be the first reaching space 150; indoctrination of children
- simple 'roll&Move' game -
cut and fold meeples out of the map first. Cut out the 'Tower' and mount it in the center of the map.
Move forward according die roll and follow instructions of the space you end on.

note:
map only, insert of youth magazin 'Frösi';
categories: Children's Game, Dice, Educational, Racing, Travel

name: Auf den Straßen des Friedens
description:
Objective: be the first reaching target space (round trip); indoctrination (translation: 'On the roads of freedom')
- simple 'roll&Move' game -
Starting in Berlin move forward according die roll and follow instructions of the space you end on.

note:
map only, insert of youth magazin 'Frösi'; likely published during 1960's
categories: Children's Game, Dice, Educational, Sports, Travel

name: Utrykning
description:
A game where each player fullfills as many emergency orders he can.

Each new order determines the address of the emergency, what kind of vehicle(s) that is needed (fire truck, ambulance or crane), the situation, the task and if there is a delay or not. The players take their corresponding vehicle(s) and moves on a cardboard board with a die roll. If more than one vehicle is needed, the task cannot be accomplished before all vehicles have arrived on the spot. Vehicles are returned to base afterwards, but new emergency calls may come on the way there (die = 1).
If an opponent's vehicle is closer to the address, and that vehicle is not currently on a mission, you can require the vehicle as your own for the mission. This vehicle could be called back if the owner needs it for an emergency of his own, but only if the vehicle is not busy with a patient (in an ambulance) or wrecked car (on the crane).

Each order gives 1-3 points if fullfilled. Winner is the player with most points when there are no more order cards (24).

Contents:
1 cardboard board with a city map
24 emergency order cards
12 rubber cars in 4 colors
1 die
1 rule sheet pasted on the back of the box lid

The game share some similarities with the later MB game: The Emergency! Game.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Pick-up and Deliver, Point to Point Movement

name: What's the Time?
description: "A Game for Learning How to Tell Time," 'What's the Time? is a children's game that offers two ways to play, each of which is designed to teach young children to tell time. In one game, children win cards by being the fastest to set their cardboard clock to the correct time as shown on the card. The first to earn a predetermined number of cards wins. In the other game, children are dealt a hand of cards and place them in a line in the order by the times shown on the cards. The first to place all his or her cards correctly wins.

name: En Toboggan
description:
A roll-and-move game for six players. The first player to reach the last space of the track wins the game.

The board shows a roller coaster-type attraction in Porte de Vincennes, Paris.

name: Die Mouson-Fahrt
description:
Objective: Be the first reaching target (Frankfurt)
- moving by turns -
Each player chooses a different route (out of four) and moves forward according die roll. Ending on a marked space follow instructions printed on the map.

note:
likely published ~ 1930 (Istanbul still named Kostantinopel)
categories: Children's Game, Dice, Educational, Racing, Travel

name: The Game of Travel
description:
From the rules:

UTENSILS. A pack of Red, White and Blue Cards, called Route Tickets, four STEAMSHIPS for travel on the water, and four TRAINS with Engines of color corresponding to the ships, for travel in Europe. It will be noticed that the trains of cars used in playing this game are like the European trains in appearance. Each player should take one STEAMSHIP and one TRAIN OF CARS of the same color. Each player should in turn draw a Red Ticket, without looking at it previously to taking it in his hand, and should put the prow of his Steamship upon the Red spot indicating the City first named on that ticket and from which port he is to sail. When traveling upon the WATER, Use the Steamship ; when going from CITY TO CITY IN EUROPE, each player should use his train as his piece, removing his Steamship from the board as soon as he begins to use his Train, and removing his train from the board when he again uses his Steamship. A player should put the front part of his Train on the City at which he is supposed to be. When ON THE WATER he should use the prow of his ship to indicate his position.

PLAYERS HAVING MADE THE FIRST MOVE continue in turn to move their pieces to the next place mentioned on their respective ROUTE TICKETS, thus: A player drawing the Route Ticket New York, Storm, Queenstown, Liverpool, and London: will it five moves, reach the latter point (using the Steamship from New York to Liverpool, then removing the Steamship front the board, and playing his Railroad Train from Liverpool to London). A player drawing the ticket New York, Rescue, Southampton and London, will, in four moves, reach the latter City, etc.

Players who prefer to use ordinary pieces instead of the Steamships and Trains of Cars, may use the four wooden pieces enclosed in the game, but if the Steamships and Trains are used, the wooden pieces are not. As a player moves his pieces, he must call out the place or city to which he moves. When a player reaches the last City named on his Ticket, he throws his Red Ticket aside (as it is not used again in the game), and continues to play and draw front White Tickets until he reaches Constantinople.

After a ticket has been used it is thrown into a discarded pile or placed under the bottom of the stack from which it was originally drawn. The players, by this process, eventually reach CONSTANTINOPLE, which is the turning point of the game.

AFTER REACHING CONSTANTINOPLE, a player must draw Blue Route Tickets, which will eventually bring him back to Boston or New York. The player making a TOUR OF EUROPE, as far as Constantinople, and first arriving at the last City mentioned on his return card (either Boston or New York), WINS THE GAME.

It will be seen that a player may make the trip very quickly, or that it may take a long time. The first Red Card that he draws will take him across the Ocean, but he may have to play upon the cities mentioned on several WHITE Cards before he reaches Constantinople, and he may draw several Blue Route Tickets after reaching Constantinople ere he gets back to Boston or New York.

N. B. — Players must move on EVERY City mentioned on EVERY Route Card they draw. Players can only move to the next City mentioned on Their Route Card, in one turn, therefore it will take six turns to reach the last City mentioned on a card having six names of Cities, etc. The red dots on the Ocean, such as Storm, Rescue, Fog, etc., supposed to represent incidents in the ocean trip, are used in the game exactly as the cities are.

GOING TO DINNER. It sometimes occurs that Two players meet in the same City, in which case they go to DINNER together, that is, both pieces are put upon the Dinner space, or picture, in the corner of the board. Players do NOT remain upon the Dinner space but remove to the next City on their routes (the Dinner only being an incident in their journey).

It does not require a SEPARATE turn to go to Dinner, the pieces being immediately placed on the Dinner picture on their meeting in any foreign City. Remember that you draw a Red Ticket on the first turn only. The White Tickets are used to carry you to Constantinople, and the Blue ones to bring you home. This will be easily remembered from the order, Red, White and Blue.

The board (from the 1st edition) sits on top of a wood framed bottom and there is a sliding drawer in the side for the game pieces to go into. The 2nd edition comes without sliding drawer.

name: Tinkers' Trials
description:
Players compete to become the new King's Engineer after the old one blew himself up.
The goal is to win 10 points worth of challenges by assembling cards into 'Works' and entering the works in Challenges as they are dealt. Different combinations of cards produce different works. Special cards provide the opportunity to do things like add special parts and steal other characters' cards or works.
Can you win the Tinkers' Trials to become the new King's Engineer?

name: Skaters Only
description:
Skaters Only™, Southwest Innovations Inc's trade name for the most realistic original skateboarding competition game, where all players are equal competitors regardless of actual skateboarding skills. The game board itself is designed with the most current terminology and state of the art graphics. Which makes Skaters Only™ the gnarliest game ever created.

The recommended ages are 6 through adult and 2 to 6 players may compete at a time. This fast-paced competition gives each player the realistic feel of being a pro skater. Each player competes through a series of seven (7) events, earning points, and brand name sponsors. Along with collecting "Pro Dough" awards. Players face the realities of the actual problems, costs, and events real pro skaters encounter. The quest of each competitor is to become the "Skaters Only™ Top Pro" by collecting the most points, pro dough, and these brand name sponsors.

name: Der goldene Ball
description:
Objective: be the first reaching target space (75),a card is drawn and you must give correct answers to 3 consecutive questions.
Soccer trivia game containing 999 questions and answers for 2-4 players. The questions are related to the soccer world championships 1990 in Italy.
Roll the die, move forward and your left neighbour draws a card. The colour of the space you end on is an indication how difficult the question is going to be. If you are successful you may roll again (max. twice)... Ending on a black space - roll&move again; yellow space - step back and skip one turn, a red card sends you back to starting position.

name: The Game of Harlequinade
description: Typical spin and move board game with unusual game board. The first player who reaches the end of the road wins the game.

name: Erntefest im Schrebergarten
description:
Objective: collect most vegetables on your move through the garden
- moving by turns -
Each player rolls the die and moves forward; ending on a red marked space you make pick up an a vegetable - if not already collected by another player. Game ends after last vegetable has been found.
note:
publisher printed on the cover: VEB Dresden
publisher mentioned inside the lid: Flechsig
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement, Set Collection
publishers: VEB Druck und Verpackung Dresden, Walter Flechsig

name: So Jemand eine Reise tut
description:
Objective: Be the first reaching space 55 (precisely)
- moving by turns -
Buy in; roll the die - anything else than a '1' let you move forward, but also pay a matching penalty until you throw a '1' during your turn. Ending on any space fulfill demanded action.
note:
cute pewter pawns
game likely published 1901 (due to different spelling on the cover of 'tut' and lid inside 'thut'); explanation: in 1901 an official change of German spelling had been introduced.
categories: Children's Game, Dice, Educational, Racing, Travel

name: 1 vorwärts 2 zurück und 3 in die Mitte
description:
Objective: Be the first placing your very last wooden stick into the centre of the board.
- acting by turns -
Split all wooden sticks equally. Active player throws 3 dice; given order: for each '1' a stick is given to the left, for each '2' to the right neighbour; for each '3' you must drop one into the centre of the board. A 4,5 or 6 let you skip this turn, also with no sticks: you must skip until you'll receive one.
If you can place your very last tick into the centre you win.
note:
likely published 1920s/30s (due to Sütterlin letters)

name: Auf der Rodelbahn
description:
Objective: be the first reaching space 60 precisely.
- moving by turns -
simple 'Roll & Move' game: move forward according die roll; around ending on a marked space follow instructions...
cute pewter pawns

name: Unsere Brummer
description:
Objective: Be the first reaching space 100
- moving by turns -
typical Roll&Move/Snakes&Ladders game; due to the WWI theme indoctrination and glorification are 'added values';
notes:
published during WWI;
impressive drawings.
categories: Children's Game, Dice, Educational, Racing, World War I

name: Epic Wars
description:
Epic Wars is a modular and expandable tile exploration and miniatures skirmish game set in the "Classic" Fantasy genre, with multiple game types and solo, co-op, and pvp modes.

Miniatures Skirmish - PVP mode:
Traditional tabletop miniatures battle game that can be played on your existing terrain, or on our Wilderness Tiles (sold separately). Each mini will have a stat card with abilities, and players will have event/action cards they can play on their turn. Each mini has an initiative and turns alternate by each individual mini, and NOT by entire squad. Squads are formed by a point system where each squad has a "point pool" and each mini has a cost.

Miniatures Skirmish - Solo, and Co-Op modes:
Similar to PVP mode with additional movement and "AI" rules (still being tweaked), to allow play against "the game". The player(s) will determine enemy squad size (point pool), and scenario prior to starting.

Tile Exploration - Solo and Co-Op modes:
A traditional dungeon tile exploration game with a few differences. Epic Wars will not only have collectable enemies cards with different levels of rarity (different stats, XP, and rewards), but all the dungeon tiles, event cards, treasure cards, trap cards, etc... will have different levels. Players will determine if they want to "free play" or if they want to use a set scenario with different objectives to complete.

And while the "wilderness tiles" are sold separately, we will be including the "dungeon tiles" in the core game. The main reason for this is many people that play tabletop skirmish games probably already have terrain of some sort, while few will already have dungeon tiles.

I'm sure this write-up has raised more questions than answered. Our goal is to maximize depth and re-playability. There is nothing worse than getting a game you are excited for and end up playing once or twice because it has the depth of a melted ice cube. Epic Wars is all about expandability and customization. And depending on your luck with the card draws and dice rolls, you could have a wipe after 5 minutes, or an Epic War lasting all day.

At this time we are still early in design and all elements are subject to change. Please send me messages and check our website for updates. Follow us and spread the word.
categories: Adventure, City Building, Exploration, Fantasy, Miniatures
mechanics: Grid Movement, Modular Board, Open Drafting, Tile Placement, Worker Placement

name: Der brave Hans und Der böse Fritz.
description:
Objective:
be the first reaching field 90
- 'Roll and Move' game, moving by turn -
players roll the die and follow instructions (glued into the lid) if they land on a marked field

note:
likely published during 1920's

name: Rein & Raus
description:
Objective: Be the first catching a head for your headless meeple and bringing it home successfully
- acting/moving by turns -
Starting from your home base each player tries to catch the head in the centre of the board, rolling the die.
If you pass another meeple wearing the head you simply take it.

note:
likely published before WWII

name: Gøy gjennom Norge
description:
A simple roll-and-move game the late 1960s. The idea of the game is to get to know the geography of Norway better.

Each player are represented on a board (map of Norway) by a plastic car. The die is rolled, and the player move forward accordingly. Landing on a yellow or red field triggers an event for that player, either through a text on the board or a random card drawn from a deck, like: "By the Malang water falls you are fishing salmon. That takes some time. Roll a 3 to move again" or "You drive through a herd of goats. Pass one roll."

First player to drive through all of Norway wins.

name: Workaholic
description:
In Workaholic, players try to get rich at the cost of their opponents; the winner is the player who has out-bought all others. But to do so, you do not only have to found companies, expand them, and sell them again, you also have to be smart, as knowledge tests are built into the game, and a certain number of knowledge markers is necessary for some of the actions.
Players move around a track; each track field allows a specific action, such as buy/develop a company, get an event card, pay other companies, secure international presence. Players get knowledge tokens by answering design- and print-related questions; these tokens can buy domain-specific knowledge markers which in turn are needed to develop the companies and give an advantage in buy-out attempts. In one sentence, a cutthroat version of "Monopoly meets Trivial Pursuit".

This game was developed in the course of a student's project in the faculty of communication design/printing and media at the Technische Fachhochschule Berlin (now Beuth-Hochschule für Technik, Berlin). The group of authors did the complete development and design work on this game, which included finding sponsors for a professional production.

Material Manifest:
1 game board
4 player mats
4 dobbers
55 company puzzle pieces
250 trivia cards
40 event cards
15 company cards
4 country cards
85 knowledge tokens
40 knowledge markers (cubes)
300 banknotes
2 6-sided dice
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Take That

name: Bikes of War: Famous Races
description:
Tired of moving reddish triplanes, expensively licensed spaceships and majestic ship-of-the-lines in endless fights on your table? Well, now for something completely different. Here you have...

BIKES OF WAR - FAMOUS RACES
A Fantasy Simulation Wargame for 2 - 99 players
by Andrea Angiolino
Artwork by Luigi Castellani

"The Immeldwarf turn gets its name from Max Immeldwarf, a famous dwarf ace: the first to receive the Gold Pedal Pour Le Merite, nicknamed in his honor 'The Glue Max' to remind how hard it was to separate him from his bicycle during the ferocious battles he took part of."

At last available in English the legendary "Bikes of War - Famous Races", the fantasy war-game of bicycle duels that more than once made it to the "Aww, please, not tonight too" list curated by the awesome play-testers at GiocAreAonLine!
Against a backdrop of wild and unspoiled nature, the nimble elven bikes and tireless dwarven mountain bikes face the orcish heavy tricycles: who will win? Among crossbow shots and shoves, punctured wheels and tumbles, a war with no quarter where only the storngest survive...
categories: Bluffing, Dice, Fantasy, Fighting, Humor, Print & Play, Sports, Transportation, Wargame
mechanics: Action Queue, Dice Rolling, Hexagon Grid, Player Elimination, Simulation, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Commute
description:
"It's been a long day at work and it's finally over. Time for a mad dash home on the evening Commute!

Hit the streets in this dynamic card game with an ever-changing board that you build as you fight to be the first player home. Endure car trouble, spontaneous detours, road construction, and your biggest threat, the other road hogs trying to beat you home."

Each player starts diagonally across the board from their color-coded home.

On each turn a player may either:
-Add to the board by playing a road space
-Move their vehicle one space along a connected road
-Play an action card on an opponent

name: Trivial Pursuit: Édition de la maison Castorama
description:
Limited edition of Trivial Pursuit for the French chain of DIY store Castorama.

Categories:
blue: history of art and architecture
pink: characters and inventions
yellow: tools and DIY
brown: brands and advertising
green: nature and gardens
orange: home and decoration

The rules are similar to the classical Trivial Pursuit.
This game was never sold in shops.

name: Rocket
description: Rocket may sound like a space-themed game, but is actually a game of racing trains. The game board is printed on the inside of its box, and consists of several tracks that narrow and widen and curve around the board with different obstacles and switches. Players use a spinner to determine their moves, and race their tin train pieces from the Start to the End of Run.

name: Trivial Pursuit: Édition de la communication (et donc de la culture)
description:
Limited edition of Trivial Pursuit for the French advertiser Avenir.

Categories:
blue: advertising
pink: media
yellow: VIPs and stars
brown: who?
green: jargon
orange: companies and products

The rules are similar to the classical Trivial Pursuit.
This game was never sold in shops.

name: Ten-To-Tal
description: Ten-To-Tal is a card game for up to four players. Included is a linen with a diagram of sixteen spaces (four by four) on it. The cards have numbers depicted with numerals and also drawings of humorous characters of the same number. The cards are shuffled and randomly drawn one at a time, and placed on an empty space on the linen. If there is a combination of cards in a row equaling ten, vertically or horizontally, that player removes those cards and keeps them. Otherwise, the card is left in place. Play continues until all the cards are used. The player with the most cards wins the game.

name: DiceFight!
description:
DiceFight! is a multi-genre dice fighting game. Each player chooses a faction with unique dice which include modified numbers and a special ability symbol, and uses this to capture objective cards. The factions in the base game include wizards, aliens, giant robots, superheroes and fairies.

On your turn you choose and roll one of your dice, plus every horde die that has previously failed to capture an objective. Objectives either have one or more dice that must be matched, or a goal like 'a 3 die straight' or '3 dice with a sum greater than 15'. Dice that are used to capture return to their owner, other dice stay in the horde and continue to be used by other players to try and capture dice. The first player to capture 10 points worth of dice wins.

name: Last Dude Standing
description:
From the box:
The Last Dude Standing Battle Set allows you to compete head-to-head against your friends using your Tech Deck Dudes.

Objective:
Knock your opponent's Dude off the platform.

Rules:
1. You and your opponent place your Dudes on the platform and move the Dude Controller until you feel the magnets stick to the controller.
2. Count to 3 then begin battling.
3. Control each Dude by moving Dude Controller back and forth and twisting the knob. The Last Dude Standing on the platform wins!

name: Twelve Rondos
description: Each player is dealt a hand of Chinese Zodiac sign cards. The current player plays a card that must be better than the previously played card, according to a specified order such as speed, weight, etc. The person who gets rid of their hand first is the winner!

name: Super Smart
description:
Super Smart (or Supersmart) is a game for 2-4 players from 9 years and up.

In this game you are are answering questions in one word beginning with a specific, but random letter.

The board consist with four independent lanes from each with a "Start" field and a passage of extra 10 steps. In the middle there is a roulette with letters (and small numbers) and six (6) coloured spots; Four (4) red ones and two (2) green ones. The game also contains four (4) player pawns (Red, Green, Blue and Yellow), one (1) die (Red with golden eyes) and a deck of Question Cards (from now called CQs).

The CQs are suffled and placed face down in reach of all players.
The youngest player starts the game by pushing the arrow of the roulette and there are following three possibility:
1) If the arrow stops at a letter the player takes a CQ and read up the question for the player on the right, who answer the question with a word starting with the letter from the roulette. The amount of time that you have to reply is agreed before the game starts. If the answer is approved the player is allowed to move one (1) step up the ladder - if not the player is not moving.
After this all other players roll the die - the player who first roll the number under the letter, can also move his/her pawn one (1) step up the ladder
2) Destiny / Red field - if the arrow stops here, all players roll the die and the player who rolls the number shown on the roulette will move his/her pawn one (1) step down the ladder.
3) Luck / Green field - If the arrow stops here, the player who spins the wheel can move his/her pawn two (2) steps up the ladder.
If the arrow stops between two fields, the player do a respin.

The first to reach the top of the ladder is the winner!
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Trivial Pursuit: Édition de la bonne humeur Apericube
description:
Small limited edition of Trivial Pursuit for the French brand Apericube.

Categories:
blue: strip cartoon
pink: movie
yellow: TV
brown: music and variety
green: humor
orange: sports and recreation

The rules are similar to the classical Trivial Pursuit.
This game was never sold in shops.


Each player has a circular playing piece with six pie-shaped holes. The goal of the game is to collect a pie in each color. The colors correspond to different question categories.

The board consists of a circular track with spaces in seven different colors. Six of the colors correspond to question categories while the last color gives a new dice roll. Six spaces along the track are "pie spaces", and from these there are "spokes" of track leading to the middle of the board.

Players roll a die and move along the track in any direction they like. When a player stops on a color they get a question of the appropriate category. If the player answers a question correctly while on a pie space, they get a pie of that color (assuming they don't already have it). A correct answer on another square allows the player to roll again.

Once the player has one pie in each color, she can move along the spokes to the middle of the board to win the game.

name: Trivial Pursuit: Humour
description:
Thematic edition of Trivial Pursuit.
Categories:
blue: movie
pink: humorists
yellow: song
brown: theater
green: media
orange: surprises

The rules are similar to the classical Trivial Pursuit.

Each player has a circular playing piece with six pie-shaped holes. The goal of the game is to collect a pie in each color. The colors correspond to different question categories.

The board consists of a circular track with spaces in seven different colors. Six of the colors correspond to question categories while the last color gives a new dice roll. Six spaces along the track are "pie spaces", and from these there are "spokes" of track leading to the middle of the board.

Players roll a die and move along the track in any direction they like. When a player stops on a color they get a question of the appropriate category. If the player answers a question correctly while on a pie space, they get a pie of that color (assuming they don't already have it). A correct answer on another square allows the player to roll again.

Once the player has one pie in each color, she can move along the spokes to the middle of the board to win the game.

name: BrainBox: Fairies
description: The object of the game is to study a card for 10 seconds and then answer a question based on the roll of a die. If the question is answered correctly, the card is kept, and the person with the most number of cards after 5 or 10 minutes is the winner.
categories: Card Game, Children's Game, Fantasy, Memory, Real-time, Trivia

name: Dead Man's Hand: Rogues' Gallery – John Bridges
description: This expantion includes miniature and card for using U.S Marshal John Bridges in your Dead Man's Hand game. Full rules are found in The Legend of Dead Man´s Hand.
categories: American West, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Wargame
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement

name: Dead Man's Hand: Rogues' Gallery – Ely Fergus
description: This expantion includes miniature and card for using Ely Fergus in your Dead Man's Hand game. Full rules are found in The Legend of Dead Man´s Hand.
categories: American West, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Wargame
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement

name: Trivial Pursuit: Édition XXème siècle
description:
This is a card set expansion to Trivial Pursuit containing 500 questions about 20th Century of the following categories:
Blue : celebrities
Pink : works and ideas
Yellow : highlights
Brown : entertainment
Green : eureka
Orange : benchmarks
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Party Game, Trivia

name: Pontoons
description:
Pontoons is played on a 6x10 grid of rectangular cells; these are almost square but a little shortened on the longest side of the board. The board is oriented with a side of six cells next to each player. These nearest six cells are called the “bank,” and to start the game, each player has six pieces called “men” in his own color, one on each cell. In the next two rows, referred to as a “mooring,” each player starts with twelve “boat” pieces of his own color. These pieces are large enough for the “men” to easily stand upon.

Players take turns moving one piece at a time, man or boat. Men may move any number of spaces vertically, horizontally, or diagonally, but not back towards their own bank. Between banks, men may only move about on or over boats. Only one man may ride a boat at a time. Boats move in the same manner as men. Men may ride a boat of either color, but the boat’s rules of movement do not change. Men may not be removed from a boat of their own color, but may be thrown overboard from one of their opponent’s boats.

Men may throw the other player’s men overboard by landing on or jumping over their boat. To do this, the opponent’s man must be in an adjacent cell; the capturing player must land on that boat or land on an empty boat opposite. A man thrown overboard returns to any empty cell on his player’s bank and begins again.

When a boat and man reach the opponent’s mooring, they are permanently removed from the board. The first player to remove all his own pieces from the board wins the game.

name: Robot Wars
description:
Find out which robot in the Robosphere has what it takes with this custom paper-crafting kit! Flex your crafting muscles and create 10 easy-to-assemble robots, each with their own personality and fighting style. Pair up any two 'bots to battle head-to-head by placing each atop the included motorized wheel bases. See who knocks the other off the fighting ring first, and keep score on the Robodrome's scoreboard. This kit also features your very own Robot Wars Combat Manual with fun background stories and directions on how to construct each rough-and-tumble machine.

Kit includes full-color templates to construct 10 paper-craft robots, 2 wind-up wheel frames, deluxe fighting ring with scoreboards, and a step-by-step instruction book complete with details on each robot's personality.

name: The Chase
description:
The Chase is played on a square wooden board with a round pit, the "hideout," carved out of the center. Four lines of small holes extend vertically and horizontally from the pit to the sides of the board, and continue around all four sides making a border. Near each corner of the board are four more small holes. Printed on the board over the lines of small holes are the outlines of footprints leading in one direction, ultimately towards the hideout. Printed over the groupings of four holes are a bomb, a noose, a gun, and a knife.

Four players have four pegs each in their own color. Play begins with their four pieces resting in one of the four corner groupings. Players take turns rolling a six-sided die to determine the length of their move. Any one of the player's pegs may be moved, but most be moved the exact number of footprints rolled on the die.

If landing on a hole occupied by another player, the first peg is returned to its home base to begin again, and the peg in play is moved five extra spaces. Players may not land on a footprint occupied by one of their own pegs; they must choose to move a different peg.

The hideout may only be reached by an exact roll of the die. If no other moves are possible, that player forfeits the turn and the peg remains in place. The first player to move all four pegs into the hideout wins the game.

name: Tilt: The Star of Card Games
description:
Tilt is a self-published card game system which utilizes a 66-card deck. The cards are divied into eight suits (A, B, F, L, O, R, S, U) with eight cards per suit (HIGH, DOUBLE, 4, 3, 2, 1, TWIN, LOW). Two other cards are included, the ROYAL E and a WILD card, each of which have a rank of 0 when necessary.

The 34 page rulebook describes seven games:
Regular Tilt
Reverse Tilt
Double Tilt
Royal Tilt
Chain Letter
Vocab
Tilt Crossword Solitaire

The Tilt family of games are trick-taking games where certain ranks are worth 1 or 2 points. One suit per player, plus one extra for a dummy hand, are used. Players bid for the right to name a trump suit, and the winner draws two cards from the dummy to improve his hand (and discarding two unwanted cards). The different versions change the rules or scoring in various ways.

Chain Letter is a stops-style game where players try to discard their hand by matching the last-played card. Only suits count, not ranks.

Vocab is a spelling game where players use the cards as letters, trying to make three-letter words. The TWIN cards count as two letters, so TWIN L is LL, TWIN A is AA, etc.

Tilt Crossword Solitaire is as it sounds, a solitaire game where the player fills an 8 by 8 grid with cards. Points are earned for letters in words or abbreviations, while they are lost for empty spaces in the grid.

The game and rulebook are copyright 1946 by William H. Mulder. The place of publication is Grand Rapids, Michigan. No manufacturer is listed.
categories: Card Game, Game System, Word Game

name: Gardener of Thoughts: Genesis
description:
GenesisThe dawn of intergalactic travel is so close that its electric body galvanizes the minds of thousands of scientists and millions of wannabe colonists.

Quantum engineering, 3D printing and artificial intelligence are pervasive branches of science, intertwined with every aspect of daily life. Everybody has access to them, everybody uses them.

The graviton is tamed and has sent the solar system abuzz, teeming with ships, robots and people.

But the dark side of humanity is showing its claws. The human civilization has been polarized by the people who want to acquire and maintain their power over the masses. The earthlings and the spacelings of this world are in conflict.

One man has breached the very wheelwork of Nature and has found a way to go anywhere in an instant, jumping through space as if walking through open doors between worlds.

The leaders of the United Planets Alliance are trying to find this man and obtain control over the greatest achievement of mankind: the obliteration of any barriers of space.

It is your destiny to intervene and set mankind on its path to the future you wish for.

Join your forces with others like you, breathe life into your faction, take part in events happening in the solar system and beyond, and bring ruin or triumph to a world which finds itself in the agony of childhood.

No man or woman has ever been closer to the future of this world. Reach up and embrace your destiny, for you have the power to bring change!






DescriptionThe Gardener of Thoughts Card Game (GOT CG) is a competitive card game for 2 players, with a science fiction theme and atmospheric lore.

The game can be played by casual players right out of the box with excellent balance. There is a single deck of cards, no other play components. Advanced players may add custom cards.

The main mechanics are: shuffled cards, card drawing, turns, card playing, abilities (whose rules are applied when cards are played), and combo actions (= combining the abilities of multiple cards played in a single turn).

The system's logic is based on the diversity of the (rules of the) abilities present on the cards, and has an emphasis on combo actions. Combo actions emerge fluidly from the abilities, and have to be created on the spot by the players. To master the game, a player has to master combo actions.

The typical game duration for veteran players, without advanced gameplay, is (consistently) 30 minutes. Beginner players (who already know the rules) need about 60 minutes.






Gameplay SynopsisMost of the time, a player has to engage (= play from hand) during his / her turns cards whose total sway (= numeric card value) is at least equal with the total sway of the cards engaged by the rival, thusly obstructing the rival.

Normally, during a turn, a player may engage only 1 card, but the abilities of the engaged cards allow for more cards to be engaged or drawn. This multiple engagement of cards is called combo action and forms the game's logic. Combo actions with 10 cards are not rare, and even with more than 20 have been seen.

From time to time, a player will not be able to obstruct the rival because he / she will not be able to create combos that are strong enough. In such a case, the player must discard 1 card from his / her reserve. Reserve is a play zone of each player, zone which contains a number of cards which is fixed at the beginning of the game; the number is normally 3, but advanced players can increase it by recruiting (= choosing) cards at the beginning of the game.

By discarding a reserve card each time when a player can't obstruct the rival, the player will have fewer cards to engage during the last turn of the game, the turn which will determine the winner of the game. However, simply having more or fewer cards in the reserve at the end of the game doesn't guarantee winning or losing the game, it just increases or decreases the chances. This is because each player also has some random cards in his / her hand, and this randomness affects the ending.
categories: Card Game, Print & Play, Science Fiction

name: Waterhout Constructionopoly
description:
A re-theme of Monopoly made for Waterhout Construction Company of St. Louis. The company has been involved in a number of commercial and residential projects over the years, including the Puffin and Penguin House at the St. Louis Zoo as well as other projects throughout the country.

11" x 11" wooden box with sliding lid.

name: Prescience
description:
Game description from the publisher:

Prescience is a two-player, action-based time travel board game. The goal of Prescience (as determined by which scenario you play) may be simple, but things become more complicated each time the players travel back in time to relive the opening of the game.

Players always control the most current version of themselves, but they have the opportunity to use their knowledge of the past to interact with their former selves — or the former versions of their opponent. Through special abilities such as pushes, pulls, and stuns, they can change the course of the previous generations. However, each time they change the past, the effects of that change continue to ripple forward as the game progresses. Players who are able to use their knowledge of the past to their advantage will be victorious in Prescience!

name: Bypass
description:
Bypass is played an a 12x12 square grid of circles, all of which are connected horizontally and vertically. There are four areas of the board in two shades each of red, blue, yellow, and green. On two opposite sides of the board is a black border numbered one through five, then skipping two spaces, and numbered five through one. A similar red numbered border exists on the board's other sides.

The game is played with up to six pieces for each player in red, blue, yellow, or green. The object is for a player to start the game with their pieces in the opposite corner of the home area of their color, and to move at least three of their pieces into that home area before their opponents, to win the game.

Movement of pieces is determined by one red and one black six-sided die; a piece will be moved to the spot where these two coordinates meet. There then follows a series of rules governing the exact part of the board the piece can move to, and what goals must be met for the piece to move further, and what happens when pieces become "triangulated," or captured.

Notes: The rules are detailed but something less than clear on some important details. Also, like other games from this publisher, the game board is a printed sheet of paper held between a transparent sheet of plastic in a black plastic frame.
publishers: Orda Industries Ltd., Skye Marketing Corporation

name: Run Sheepee Run
description:
The board for Run Sheepee Run begins with a 3x3 square grid of nine holes, with four similar grids branching out from the corner holes of the center square, for a total of 41 holes. One black marble (the wolf) and twelve white marbles (the sheep) are included with the game, and rest easily in the board's holes.

To start the game, the wolf places his marble anywhere on the board. The sheep then places a marble anywhere on the board. The wolf may begin moving to one adjacent hole in any direction. The sheep must continue placing his marbles one at a time anywhere on the board until they have all been placed. At that point, the sheep marbles can move the same as the wolf.

The wolf can capture any sheep in an adjacent hole by jumping over it to a vacant hole on its opposite side and removing it from play. Multiple jumps are possible. The sheep cannot capture but must try to crowd the wolf so that it cannot move, either with white marbles or against the edge of the board. If the sheep trap the wolf, they win. If the wolf can no longer be trapped, he wins.

This is a variant of Fox and Geese.

name: Teddy auf Reisen
description:
Objective: be the first reaching space 90
- moving by turns -
Roll the die and move forward. If you land on one of the special blue or red marked spaces, you must obey the instructions glued into the lid.

note:
likely published early 1920's
categories: Animals, Children's Game, Dice, Fantasy, Racing

name: Die Fahrt durch den Panamakanal
description:
Objective: be the first reaching space 50/1
- moving by turns -
Choose one of the two routes (red or black: Panama - Colon or vice versa): Roll the die and move forward. If you land on one of the special marked spaces, you must obey the instructions glued into the lid.

Note:
Likely published ~1915 (not earlier than 1914/not later than early 1917 - Germany at war with USA)
categories: Children's Game, Dice, Educational, Nautical, Racing, Travel

name: KLIC Bowling
description:
KLIC Bowling is played on a plastic board reminiscent of a bowling alley, with a bowling lane for throwing two-six sided dice, and ten holes arranged like bowling pins, labeled with numbers one through ten and with plastic pegs that fit inside. A score pad is also provided.

On each turn a player rolls the dice and removes pegs based on the outcome, then tries to remove as many more pegs as possible by jumping as in Checkers or Solitaire puzzles. When no more moves are possible, the score is tallied exactly as in real bowling games. A second roll of the dice is then allowed, to attempt to remove any pegs remaining. The next player then resets the pegs and takes his turn.

Rolling a double on the first dice throw is a strike, rolling a double on the second throw is a spare. Players track their scores in a regular bowling score format, with the winner being the player scoring the highest number of points in ten frames.

name: Trivial Pursuit: Édition Europe
description: A subsidiary card set for use with the master game. Contains 400 cards, 2400 questions in six categories: Places in Europe, Life in Europe, European Affairs, Culture of Europe, European cousins, Champions of Europe.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Party Game, Trivia

name: Kirdy
description:
Making words from letters drawn at random is common to many word games! But add a little cunning, an element of chance, some audacity and a lot of strategy and you get Kirdy, a word game like no other word game! You can challenge your opponents, and take their points by gambling on your wits! Beware though, as the sand falls ever too quickly through the egg-timer, the pressure builds!

The game starts with two letters and becomes progressively more difficult as new letters are added. Drawing an extra letter tile after each word, the player has to find a new word, each time betting before the draw that he will be able to do so. The word has to contain the letters drawn, in the right order.

name: The Lion and the Mouse
description:
The Lion and the Mouse is a spin-and-move game for two or four players. Each player has a Lion, a Mouse and a Hunter piece. The object of the four player game is to be the first to move one's Lion and Mouse pieces from their color's Start space to the corresponding Lion's Den space. In the two player game, each player controls two colors and must move both of their Lion and Mouse pieces to the appropriate dens.

Each piece has unique traits: the Hunter can "trap" (lock down) a Mouse or send a Lion back to its Start space; the Mouse can free a Lion from a trap; the Lion can send a Hunter back to its start space from outside a trap space. The spinner determines which piece may move, though some spinner spaces permit the player to choose.

name: Eduscho
description:
Objective: Be the first reaching space 50 precisely
- moving by turns -
each player starts with 3 meeples on three different routes (tea, coffee, cacao) trying to reach space 25 (production unit) precisely.

Ending on a marked space follow instructions.
Successfully finished you have to move your big meeple up to space 50 (consumer).

Note:
Likely published 1960's; large folded map was sent out in a mailer.

name: The Philadelphia Game
description:
The object of the game is to have fun and learn more about the past and present of America's birthplace. A secondary object is to "win" the game by either controlling the entire city and forcing the other players out of the game or possess the most cash value at the end of an agreed on time period - 60 minutes, 90 minutes or whatever.

To start the game everyone begins at Independence Hall and receives $1776.00. Players take turns in order moving the allotted number of spaces (dice roll) in a clockwise direction around the board. If a player lands on a property with special instructions, they must be followed. If the player lands on an unowned property, it may be purchased. If the player lands on a property owned by another player, then rent must be collected. If the player lands on a property they already own, that player than receives rent from the bank. If a player rolls doubles, they roll again. A second roll of doubles send that player to the Roundhouse.

A player may sell any properties they own to any other player at any time during the game. The bank is forces to buy back any property a player choose at 67% of the original cost. The rent of each property is 10% of its original cost. If a players owns two properties of a kind (for example the Art Museum and the Academy of Music - cultural institutions) the rent is doubled. If a player owns three properties the rent is tripled. A player may not collect any rents while his pawn is at the Roundhouse or on the Expressway.

Whenever a player rolls a "one" that player gets to draw a Travel card. Whenever a player rolls a "six" that player gets to draw a News card. If a player rolls both a "one" and a "six" on the same roll that player can select either type of card, but not both. If double "ones" or "sixes" are rolled, that player draws nothing. When a player ends their turn on a block marked "Travel Card" or "News Card" that player draws the appropriate card. A player that ends their turn on either the Free Library or Franklin Institute gets to answer a Quiz card drawn by the player on their left. The "correct" answers to the Quiz cards are left to the discretion of the game players.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: Autorennen
description: This is a car race, so obviously the winner is the one who is the first to reach the finish line. The movement of the racing cars is determined by a die. Several segments of the race track have special rules, like the results of the die counting double or half. The Players get two different kinds of cards they may use during the race instead of rolling the die. The red spurt cards allow the car to advance from a space with a yellow arrow to the next space with a red tableau. The green attack cards allow a car to exchange it's positon with any one opponent on the throw of an even number. But beware: If the die shows an odd number, the car remains on it's position and doesn't advance at all.
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Confounded
description:
Confounded is a game for two, played on a 3x9 rectangular grid of squares. Each player has nine pieces, or "spots," in their own color. The board is divided into three 3x3 sections, with each player claiming one side and the central territory in dispute. Three each of a player's "spots" are marked with either the number one, two, or three. The game begins with the three spots in the row closest to the players, the two spots in the next row inward, and the one spots in the next row.

Players take turns moving one piece at a time and try to claim the central area or prevent their opponent from doing so. All spots move only forward. One spots move one square diagonally. Two spots move two squares directly forward. Three spots move either two squares forward and one square sideways, or one square sideways and two squares forward.

Capture of pieces is by displacement and there are a number of rules governing it. To win the game, a player must occupy five squares of the central area, or block his opponent from moving, or reduce his opponent to less than five pieces.

name: Coloration
description:
Coloration is played on a 17x17 grid of squares. Some squares are marked with a circle in one of eight colors; these squares form diagonal lines crossing the board from corner to corner and side to side. The board's central square is marked with a red diamond. The game includes 154 square tiles: 15 red, 25 orange, 35 yellow, 35 green, 25 blue, 15 violet, and 4 "stopper" tiles, which are half black and half color. Racks are included for each player.

The tiles are placed face down in a "pool." Each player draws seven tiles to make his "hand," and will continuously draw again to maintain a hand of seven. Players begin placing their tiles on the board, attempting to make "sequences" of colors. The rules provide for a number of these, including a rainbow sequence, a hot spectrum sequence, a cold spectrum sequence, and more. These sequences incorporate the existing colors of the board and are governed by still more rules.

Different levels of points are scored for each sequence as players complete their turns. Play continues until no more sequences are possible; the player with the most points wins the game.

name: Cow Cents
description:
MOOOVE your Money Tokens to the money pool to match the amount on the Goal card and the Money Tokens are yours! Don’t worry if you can’t make a total match, you can cash in your Cow Token and the pool is yours! Have the Money Tokens with the most dollar value at the end of the game and win!

Add Money Tokens to money pools to reach goal amounts. Match the goal exactly and collect all the tokens from that pool. Be careful not to exceed the goal amount or the Money Tokens from that money pool will go to the other players. Players calculate the monetary value of the Money Tokens they’ve collected and the player with highest total wins!

Features

Monetary Values
Adding and Subtracting Amounts
Adaptive Strategy

name: Board At Sea
description:
Board at Sea is a pirate themed strategy game for 2 players that takes about half an hour.

The board shows 2 ships, side by side, and the rope bridges that connect them. Start by standing your stones on your ship so that your opponent can't see what they are. On each turn you'll move a piece and roll dice to resolve attacks. Your crew moves between ships, the cannons fire across the board, and the treasure tries its best to stay hidden.

The pirates win by stealing one of the treasure chests and bringing it back to their ship, and the merchants win if they can stop the pirates.

name: Sea Stories
description:
Sea Stories is a pirate themed storytelling game for 2-4 players that takes about an hour.

The board shows a grid with difficulty ratings surrounded by quick descriptions of the story elements. Start by choosing whether each player will be a Fresh Fish or Salty Dog. On each turn you'll roll the dice and tell a story based on what you roll. The number of story elements you use determines your placement on the board. If the other players catch an interaction you forgot, they'll call hornswaggle and prevent you from placing a piece.

The first person to get a three-in-a-row wins the game.

name: The Blockade
description:
The Blockade is a pirate themed strategy game for 2 players that takes about half an hour.

The board shows a sea with marked starting spaces and pirate island on one side. Start by placing your ships on the marked spaces and setting the difficulty. On each turn you'll move one of your ships. Pirates are more maneuverable, but there are only 3 of them. The navy moves slower, but has a large fleet.

The pirates win if they can get just one treasure back to the island, and the navy wins if they can stop the pirates.

name: Liaoshen Campaign, 1948
description:
Liaoshen Campaign(遼瀋戰役), 1948 is a 2-4 players operational-level board wargame that simulates the battles between Chinese Communist Party (CCP,中國共產黨) and Kuomintang (KMT,中國國民黨) from Sep, 1948 to Nov, 1948 during the second Chinese Civil War. It is the first game in the Chinese Civil War Series(CCWS,國共內戰系列). 2 players command the People Liberation Army (PLA), and the other 2 players command the National Government Army (NRA) respectively.

Each turn represents 7 days and each hex is about 10 km across. There are several kinds of basic combat units, including infantry, artillery, artillery, cavalry, armor, etc. The scale of the basic unit is from regiment to division size. There are three phases in the sequence of play, strategic, operational, and supply phases. During the strategic phase, player use strategic move to deploy your units to the right place quickly. During the operational phase, players use cards to activate the corps HQ to command its units to move, combat, and advance after combat. You can also use cards to initiate some events or special tactics during combat. During supply phase, you produce the resource points from the city/town you occupied and refill your hand cards.

There are four scenarios in this game, including Liaoshen Campaign (7 turns), Battle of Jinzhou (4 turns), Battle of Heishan (3 turns), Huludao evacuation (2 turns). The victory condition is different from both sides in different scenarios.
categories: Card Game, Civil War, Dice, Wargame
mechanics: Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Dice Rolling, Hexagon Grid

name: Fuhrmanns-Leut' sind lustige Leut'
description:
Objective: Be the first reaching Leipzig
- moving by turns -
each player determines (by die) his/her starting point - you must roll your die until you get a different starting number/position.
Move according die roll into indicated direction (clockwise/contraclockwise) around the board. If the space is already occupied you end on skip one turn.
After you have finished one round head for Leipzig. Ending on a marked space follow instructions glued into the lid.
categories: Children's Game, Dice, Educational, Racing, Travel

name: Gute Fahrt durch unser deutsches Vaterland!
description:
Objective: Be the first reaching Berlin (making a round trip - red route) - main game
- moving by turns -
Roll the die and move forward. If you end on a marked space, follow the instructions glued into the lid.

Note:
There are a few different routes (yellow and blue) with slightly different rules. It's remarkable, that at that time a GDR publisher produced a game with routes through all of Germany.
categories: Children's Game, Dice, Educational, Racing, Travel

name: Last Saga
description:
Last Saga is a skirmish wargame played with 32mm miniatures.

Different factions fight against each other in a science-fiction universe: The Council, survivors of the human race; Uruhvel, users of powerful biotechnology; Raiders of Saanar, corsairs and pirates eager for loot; Guardians of Tanaor, high and proud of their advanced technology.

Games portray confrontations between two small groups of units controlled by players, filled with action and where tactics are key to victory!

Receive your actions each turn and use them wisely on your units. Examples of actions are: "Fire and movement", "Rapid fire", "Race", etc.

Every situation is resolved by a 2D6 roll, on a fast paced action where you will not lose sight of the game goal: accomplish the mission.

Configure your Combat Force, set the mission, and work for the success!

name: Titanic-opoly
description:
Inspired by the Titanic – The World’s Largest Museum Attraction, the board game allows you to re-live the grandeur of the ill-fated ship. But don’t become too immersed in the history, your aim is to buy up all the sea-faring properties and win the game!

Join your opponents and sail through Titanic history while buying up your favorite Titanic rooms and galleries in 1st, 2nd, and 3rd class - but don't run out of cash. Try to avoid paying port taxes and watch out for ice fields ahead.

Features:

Full colour game board with a Titanic theme.

“Purser's Office” and “Ice Field” cards replace traditional Community Chest and Chance cards.

Money is printed with a helm design.

Includes six collectible tokens – anchor, shovel, coal, captain's hat, helm and key.

Traditional houses and hotels are renamed “Cabins” and “Suites”.

Set also includes two dice and an instruction booklet with the rules of the game, plus rules for 60-minute speed play game.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Stock Holding, Trading

name: From The Ranks To Field Marshal
description: A game produced in Britain during the First World War for the soldiers at the front. Each player enlists as either a Private, Sapper, Gunner or Trooper depending on which arm of the armed forces they join, and as they progress around the board they get promoted through the ranks. Whoever becomes Field Marshall is the winner. Along the way are various events which may accelerate or hinder your progress.

name: Das Schlaue Musikrodil
description:
This is a quiz game where the players have to answer questions about music theory, instruments and history in order to advance and collect the name, birth of date and portrait of specific composers.

Contents:
1 Board
1 Rulebook with the answers to the questions.
320 Question cards.
100 Composer cards
8 Gameplys figures
2 Dice
mechanics: Open Drafting, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Deep Dig
description:
A press-your luck card game with an underground theme.

Players play as treasure hunters exploring deep underground, facing monsters such as giant earthworms and lava swimmers, and dangers such as narrow bridges and tunnel collapses.

Each turn the active player purchases tool cards with various special abilities. Then they encounter monster and danger cards from the dig deck until either they choose to stop digging or a card knocks them out. They score treasure based on the number of cards they encountered that turn, but only if they weren't knocked out.

Once the dig deck is depleted, whoever has the most treasure wins.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Open Drafting, Push Your Luck

name: Quaff
description:
Quaff is a collectible card game with fast-paced gameplay and a sense of humour.

The object of Quaff is to eliminate all other players whilst simultaneously attempting to remain in the game. Pick a deck - be that the horde of zombies, the superhero, the spaceship, or the fantasy army - and sparingly play cards to take down your opponents.

At the start of each round, players bid to determine the total cost of the cards they can play this round - however this is linked to the amount of drink consumed. Cards, ranging from permanents (which remain in play until removed by the effects of another card) to counters (which can be used on an opponent's turn to hinder their strategy), are utilised to decrease a player's life points. Once they reach 0, they are eliminated.

name: Top Billing
description:
From the publisher's website:

Welcome to Top Billing! In this game, you and your friends become competing movie producers working on a film. Your objective is to duke it out with the others to put your unique imprint on the final film by gathering Actors, Sets, and Props. By strategically putting them together to earn you the most points, you can earn the title of executive producer and Top Billing!
categories: Card Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: DeckQuest
description:
Welcome to DeckQuest, a light RPG-simulating card game!

This game has been designed to be a simple yet fulfilling light RPG adventure in card format. This game requires no dice, no character sheets, no miniatures, and no complicated math.

DeckQuest is easy to set up: simply select your character (one of four) and the relevant stat cards. Select your adventure--dungeon or outdoors--and create your adventure deck. The adventure deck consists of path cards, monsters, events, and locations. Your goal? Defeat the dragon for fame and glory!

DeckQuest has very little text and uses simple yet expandable rules, making it a great "gateway" game for kids or non-gamers, but enough depth to make it a great filler game for more advanced players. It requires no dice or any supplies--just the cards!
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Modular Board, Role Playing

name: Psyborg
description:
Augmented to be more than human, you have but one task: save the last of humanity!

You are a Psyborg. You have been augmented to be more than human with robotic limbs and powers of telekinesis. You have but one task: save the last of humanity! But it isn't going the way you expected... Other Psyborgs are out there, trying to kill you while they steal the glory of saving humanity!

Your Job:
• Kill other Psyborgs!
• Find, steal and protect humans!
• Make sure you are the last Psyborg standing with a human under your protection!

The Rules:

• Shuffle all the cards, minus the rules cards, together
• Deal everyone two cards
• Determine who goes first
• At the start of turn, draw a card
• After drawing a card players can choose to play a card from their hand or pass.
• If there are no more cards to draw, shuffle the discard pile into the draw pile.
• The winner is the last player left alive with a human in their hand.

Each card has different effects - Shields block all cards used against you, Humans are to be protected and discarding one means you are out of the game, EMP Pulses forces a player to discard a card of their choice, Scans reveal Humans, etc...

If you don't have a Human card in hand, you want to find and take one from another player. If you do have a Human, you want to protect it from other players. Attack other players, but make sure you have a Human by the end of the game, or everyone loses.

Location for high-quality PnP files is located here.
The Game Crafter page of the game is located here.

This game won first place for the 24 hour contest - May 2014.
categories: Card Game, Deduction, Print & Play, Science Fiction

name: Word Throwing Game
description:
Word Throwing Game is a word dice game where players take turns and roll the dice once. They form words of four or more letters. Blank sides are wild.

Scoring:

Each letter used scores 5 points.
Players score a bonus of 25 points for spelling their first name.
Players score a bonus of 50 points for using all 12 dice.

The first player to reach 500 points is the winner.

name: Throw-A-Word
description:
A word dice game with 12 letter dice.

Players roll the dice and make words of three or more letters. Blank sides are wild.

Scoring:


1 point for each letter used
35 bonus points for spelling Throw or Word


If a player uses all 12 dice, he gets a free roll.

The winner is the first person to reach 200 points.

name: Challenge
description:
Challenge is a word dice game similar to Poker Challenge. Players roll the letter dice and try to form words to score points. However, it is different because of its board with red and blue boxes which can double or triple letters and words.

It is for two to ten players. Everyone plays in turn for two minutes.

name: Texarkana Trivia
description: Texarkana Trivia is a knock-off of Trivial Pursuit, focused on local trivia about the Texas-Arkansas-Louisiana (Tex-Ark-Ana) tri-state area. Two to four players roll-and-move around a board decorated with local businesses, answer questions about local history and miscellanea, and collect four colored pegs for their pawn. The first player to bring a pawn with all four pegs to the center wins!
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: State Master
description:
Learn key facts about the 50 states in the United States of America playing this fun, easy-to-learn card game!

State Master is simple to learn, easy to set up, requires little space, can be played in as little as 10 minutes, and keeps all players engaged throughout as everyone plays in every round (i.e., no waiting your turn!).

You and your kids will learn each state's:


Abbreviation
Capital
Largest City
Year of Statehood
Nickname
Population Rank
Location on the Map


A BETTER WAY OF LEARNING FACTS
While flash cards are great for committing facts to short-term memory, they don't engage kids for long. Games provide a good alternative, but in most "educational" games, the learning comes slowly as players must wait their turn to get a question and rarely get the same question twice in the same game.

In State Master, all players participate in every turn, so everyone is learning and testing their knowledge constantly. Player who get the wrong answer take a quick moment to study all six facts on the state card and then try to get the same card the next turn, immediately putting their new knowledge to use.
