A sourcebook for the Western Frontier Protectorate Army 08th Airborne Regiment, this book requires use of
Heavy Gear Blitz! Locked & Loaded, Return to Cat's Eye, and Heavy Gear RPG 2nd & 3rd editions.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Science Fiction, Wargame

name: Heavy Gear Silhouette Core Miniature Rules
description:
From the back cover;

To celebrate the 10th Anniversary of Heavy Gear, we bring you the new 3rd Edition of miniature rules! The new Silhouette Core Heavy Gear Miniature Rules takes the acclaimed Silhouette game mechanics to the next level, with game play from one on one Melee Scale to massive Fleet Scale battles. The Tactical Scale has been revamped to speed up the game and save time on record keeping. Rules updates include improved Command Point
usage, streamlined ammunition tracking, plus new artillery, air and orbital strikes rules.

The best in Giant Robot miniature games just got better!

The Silhouette Core Heavy Gear Miniature Rules includes rules for the following:
• Tactical Scale, the main Heavy Gear miniature battle scale.
• Melee Scale, character-scale battles with rules for converting SilCORE RPG characters into miniature stats.
• Duelist Scale, for one on one duelist gear battles in close quarters skirmishes.
• Fleet Scale, massive battles with landships and squad stands.
• Weapon tables, combat tables and datacards included.

A core miniature game rulebook for all players; a few six-sided dice, miniatures, measuring tape, pen and paper are required to play the game.

For two to six players, age 8 and older.

80 Pages; August, 2005
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Science Fiction, Wargame

name: Robopoly: Het beroemde gezelschapsspel
description:
A monopoly (from Greek monos μόνος (alone or single) + polein πωλεῖν (to sell)) exists when a specific person or enterprise is the only supplier of a particular commodity.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements from Diagned, a pharmaceutical distribution division in the Netherlands.
mechanics: Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Stock Holding, Trading

name: Insane Traffic
description:
Insane Traffic is a card and dice game that simulates the traffic situations in Metro Manila, Philippines. You are an everyday driver living in Metro Manila and the goal of the game is to get the most number of points by reaching check points in different areas of Metro Manila.

The game has a great balance of dice rolling for movement (to depict the randomness of traffic) and hand management to add chaos and skill to the game. Insane Traffic is also an educational game wherein players must be able to recognize the different traffic signs in the game to increase their chances of winning.
categories: Action / Dexterity, Card Game, Dice, Educational, Racing, Transportation
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Hand Management, Modular Board, Roll / Spin and Move, Simulation, Take That

name: Trilemma
description:
Trilemma is an abstract game, where players make simultaneous moves in order to create a pattern of stones in their color.

The players each secretly choose a numbered stone they wish to place on the board and then reveal simultaneously. Uncontested stones are placed in the desired spot. If players choices conflict, a non-conflicting player claims the spot according to a simple deterministic rule.

First player to create a line of three stones in his color, wins the round and thereby two poins. First player to 10 points wins the game.

Playing the game involves bluffing, smart choices and banter. It offers the feel of a 'dilemma for three', hence Trilemma!

name: Ef-One
description:
Over 40,000 sold. Published in Shanghai, in Chinese, with English names and slogans as an added-on educational element.

Car racing game using cards. Three different games using the same cards: a two player card 'duel', lasting 10-30 minutes; a 2-10 player moving-around-the-track game for younger players; and a combo of the two, a 2-10 player moving-around-the-track game using the cards to interact with the others.

Backs of the cards represent a straight section of track. Fronts: left and right wide and left and right tight curves, an S-curve, a finish line, a dry/wet tire card, a sun/rain weather card, a thick perforated card with 5 two-sided cars, and 45 playing cards, in 26 types and 4 different colours representing maneuvers, special ations and anti-card actions. Also included is a handy 14-page full-colour fold-out booklet with all the rules, illustrated examples and a list of the game components.

On the accompanying website (now defunct) the games could be played substituting pictured cards for the real ones.

name: Mare Balticum: The Fate of an Empire
description:
Mare Balticum - the Board Game© is a board game about production, trade and war around the Baltic Sea. The players take on the roles of noble lines during the Swedish Empire Era. Together, they will populate the kingdom, build ships for overseas trade, build armies for overseas war and build forts for defending the gains. Instead of fighting each other, they will have to fight the enemies around the Baltic Sea, competing for the same provinces. However, the best for the kingdom is not necessarily the best for your noble line. You have to decide what benefits you most: production or trade, consolidation or expansion, war or peace. But will your objectives coincide with your opponents' objectives? Beware, if you fight internally, your external enemies will conquer the entire kingdom and put an end to both the Swedish Empire Era and the game!

Game mechanisms include

1. Player balance: The players have a limited number of units, preventing one from growing too strong.
2. Game balance: The rate that the enemies grow is related both to the number of players and to their current strength, preventing them from getting too strong or too weak.
3. Production vs Trade vs War balance: The players may choose different strategies for growing and one strategy chosen will bring negative effects to the other strategies.
4. Cooperation: The players build fleets, armies and forts together and they also fight battles together.
5. Prisoners' dilemma. One player may benefit by not cooperating but if all do so, all will lose.

name: X-Plus: extension lettres
description: A set of 25 wooden cubes with letters to replace the colored cubes from the base game. With these, the goal of the game changes; players should now align the cubes to make a 5 letter word.

name: Who's Riding on the Bus?
description:
The animals are out for a fun ride.

Move your bus around your game board searching for the one winning solution that matches how the animals are sitting in the bus. Be the first player to find it... and you win!

This is a children's learning game that focuses on: matching, image recognition, and concentration.

name: Across the Void
description:
Across the Void is a Space Trader board game for one to four players that focuses on trade negotiations with alien merchants, as well as management of and interaction with crew members.

You are the captain of a small deep void trade ship. Under your command are five crew members; each with specific skills. You must manage your crew so their overall Morale, Loyalty, and Efficiency Ratings are as high as you can get them. That way, your crew will perform their tasks more efficiency when needed.

Travel through Hyperspace is dangerous, and requires successful Skill Tests of your crew. Sustaining damage is costly, in terms of spending money on repairs, and the potential loss of crew, ship's systems, and cargo.

The object of the game is to be the first Captain to accumulate 1000 Galactic Credits by buying Goods, transporting them safely through Hyperspace, and then selling them at negotiated prices on distant worlds.

Player vs Player interaction occurs, as well as card-driven NPC combat events. In addition to accommodating multiple players, this game is designed for Solitaire play.
categories: Economic, Negotiation, Science Fiction, Space Exploration

name: CyberPsi: Agenda
description:
INTRODUCTION

Futuristic game of missions and agenda for two to three players set in a dystopian CyberGlam city hovering in the upper atmosphere.

Players are leaders of different factions vying for control of the hovering city of Lithica.

GAME OBJECTIVE

The object of the game is to complete missions that allow you to realize your faction's agenda. Doing so allows you to expend resources in order to add buildings, statuary, bill boards, and groups throughout the city. These installations expand your influence, giving you control of city sectors.

The first player to control a predetermined number of city sectors wins the game.

ENACTING AGENDA

At the start of the game, each player selects a faction-oriented Agenda Card to put into play. This is called enacting an agenda.

Agenda Cards list five different types of Missions your agents must complete. Once they have completed three or more different missions from the list, the agenda is considered realized, and you are awarded a specified number of Influence Points. These points can then be spent on placing installations on the game board.

COMPLETING MISSIONS

Mission Cards list five different types of Actions our agents must complete while in neutral- or enemy-controlled locations. Once three or more different actions from the list are completed, the mission is completed. You gain the listed benefits from the mission, and the Mission Card is then placed face-up under the Agenda Card (for scorekeeping purposes).

COMPLETING ACTIONS

Each agent in the game has a primary function; such as: eliminating, seducing, capturing, corrupting, or turning enemy agents. To perform its function, an agent must be in a city sector, or sector location, that contains a keyword matching the same keyword on the agent's card.

CyberPsi utilizes polyhedron. An action attempt may require you to roll 1d4 or 1d12 to determine how many Action Points an agent musters when attempting the action. Asset Cards that are equipped to the agent sometimes adds to an action attempt's Action Point total.

Thus, a Rank 1 Hacker in a location with the keyword INTERFACE may try to "Steal (1) Data Card from target enemy Database." The Action Point Value needed to successfully perform this action is (12). In order to be able to reach this, you roll 1d8 (as indicated on his card) and add (2) Action Points provided by his "Jac-in-Boxx" Asset Card and (1d4) Action Points provided by his "Virtualization Headgear" Asset Card. The total number of Action Points your Hacker gets is (13), which exceeds the target value of (12). Thus, the action attempt is successful, and your agents enables you to take anyone Data Card from the target player's Database.

RESOURCES

During the course of the game, you will assign agents to undertake activities that generate resources. You can then expend these resources to put other agents into play, to buy Asset Cards, and to unlock cards that can be placed into your draw deck.

COMBAT

Combat in CyberPsi is resolved by rolling each combatant's die type (d4, d6, d8, etc), adding any modifiers provided by Asset Cards, and comparing the results to each other. Damage is determined and applied, and the battle continues or ends, depending on combat situational factors.

Some agents have Combat Abilities that impact attack order, targeting, and damage.
categories: Abstract Strategy, Action / Dexterity, Card Game, City Building, Dice, Fighting, Miniatures, Political, Science Fiction, Spies/Secret Agents, Territory Building
mechanics: Action Points, Area Majority / Influence, Area Movement, Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Dice Rolling, Secret Unit Deployment, Simultaneous Action Selection, Tile Placement, Worker Placement

name: Biberburgen
description:
The Beavers have to build lodges and collect winter stores, but always have to expect flooding and interference by other beavers from the neighboring areas.

Each player starts with a pair of beavers and a set of trees in different colors. On your turn you roll a dice and move a beaver. If he comes to a tree field, he may take the tree in his stock or build it in the lodge. Two Beavers on marginal fields carry out a turf war: This is decided with dice: who rolls higher wins. The winner can take a tree in the lodge or a tree as a food supply from the loser. Who first completes his lodge and fills his sfood supply wins.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Modular Board, Set Collection

name: The Art of Christian Conversation
description:
A new game from the makers of The Art of Conversation: The Art of Christian Conversation

From the website:
The Art of Christian Conversation is an innovative and inspiring way for Christians, (and those exploring) to get to know themselves - and God - better. Carefully researched, tested, trialled and refined, TAOC Christian offers new angles and avenues to think about, and discuss, Christian faith and life.

Louise Howland and Keith Lamb, authors of the original best-selling titles, TAOC The Art of Conversation, have collaborated for this special edition with Ross and Suzette Bowerman.

With 300 Christian Communication-builders ranging from the profound to the light-hearted, plus a comprehensive Christian Communication Guidebook, TAOC makes it easy to share and discuss feelings, ideas and experiences related to faith and religious living in a harmonious way.

Like all TAOC editions, it’s not a quiz – and whilst there are myriad of opportunities to learn, it’s never about who knows the most. Rather, it’s a communication tool that draws on personal experiences, thoughts and reactions to facilitate fascinating discussions and new insights. It also encourages clear communication and respectful listening.

TAOC is a handy icebreaker when a new group of people come together and helps people who already know each other take their relationships to new levels. Ideal for small groups, bible study, fellowship, education and the home, TAOC can be played by family, friends, workmates, students or even solitary players. TAOC is suitable for players aged from four to 104.

name: Letter-Rou
description:
From the inside of the lid:
"Object of the game is to make as many words as possible from the ten (10) letters obtained by spinning the wheels"

Each player has a set of markers and a mini-roulette wheel of the same color. Each hole on the wheel corresponds to two letters of the alphabet and a number. The board is divided into quadrants, each having a color matching a wheel and a hole where the wheel sets into. Players play only on their like-colored quadrant.

Each quadrant shows an alphabet list. Players spin their own wheels 5 times to get a set of 10 letters, marked with a disk on the board. When the 10 letters are obtained, the sand timer is flipped and players race to make the most words from their letters.

The game advertised 6 games total that can be played. However, the main game, described above, requires some skill. The other 5 (including one using the numbers on the wheels) are completely luck driven.

name: To The Ends of the Earth
description:
To the Ends of the Earth is a fully-cooperative adventure game based on the 1930's adventure serials. Players take on the roles of intrepid explorers traversing the globe in search of ancient artifacts while trying to outwit and outrun enemy agents.

The game begins with the players choosing a mythical artifact, which will serve as the McGuffin for the game. Each artifact will have a series of clues that are distributed around the world.
Clues take several forms: They can be excavation sites, scraps of historical documents, ancient relics, or even people who may be able to help the players deduce the location of the artifact. Each clue that is collected brings the players on step closer to discovering the artifact’s final resting place. Players will have to act fast as enemy agents (controlled by the game) will be hot on their heels collecting clues and setting ambushes at every turn!

Combat in EotE takes the form of action sequences, or confrontations with the enemy villain that happen periodically throughout the game. Players work together to defeat enemy minions by using their weapons, special abilities, teamwork, and most importantly, the environment around them. Furniture such as crates, explosive barrels, tables, and even bottles of whiskey can be used and manipulated by the players to give them the upper hand in any battle. Find yourself staring down the barrel of a Tommy Gun? Flip over the nearest table for cover! Cornered by a band of hired muscle? Grab the nearest whiskey bottle, set it alight, and toss it at an explosive crate to create the perfect getaway!

To the Ends of the Earth is the board game where you, the players, truly determine the course of your adventure! Fight vigilantly to defeat the enemy villain, recover the artifact, and win the game!

EotE features a unique Action Dice allocation system to determine the options available to each player during their turn. Each player will choose an adventurer to control for the duration of the game. Each adventurer has three "stats", which determine their proficiency for different tasks:

Brawn determines a character’s Strength, Speed, and Endurance, and is used for physical tasks such as brawling, climbing, or using melee weapons.

Skill describes a character’s Dexterity, Coordination, and Awareness. Using firearms, disarming traps, and driving vehicles are made much easier with a high Skill Stat.

Wits relates to a character’s Intelligence, Problem-Solving, and Inter-Personal skills. A high Wits Stat is needed to conduct research, excavate dig sites, or issue commands to allies and other characters.

At the beginning of each turn, a player will roll their available Action Dice (five six-sided dice if their character is healthy). Each die rolled below a Stat may be used for an action that requires that Stat.

Actions include movement, researching artifacts, brawling with enemies, using firearms, or manipulating the environment. Special abilities and equipment broaden the choices available to each player, and with so much potential to strategize, there is never a ‘bad roll’. Every action you take will have consequences that ripple through the rest of the game, creating a unique adventure each time you play!

name: Das Feuerrote Teufelchen
description:
Das Feuerrote Teufelchen (The Fire-Red Devil) is an abstract chase designed for Spiel sets.

The "devil" player attempts to overtake the "angel" player, while the angel aims to keep moving until the cubes run out. Each time either player moves, the vacated space is filled with a neutral cube from a limited supply.

name: Spiritual Warfare
description:
Spiritual Warfare is everything you want in a game! It is strategic, engaging, innovative and offers players the chance to use a different strategy EVERY TIME they play. Acquire Spirit Points to win! Defend yourself with the help of Angels! Demolish your opponents with twelve different Demons.

Each player starts the game with an equal number of Character Cards, 4 Orb Cards, 1 Angel and 1 Demon. The board is set with 5 Orb Cards to draw from, and the rest of the Orb Cards are placed to the left of the pool. There are Black, Red, Blue White, Green and WILD Orb Cards. Black & Red Orbs can be used to purchase Demons. Blue & White Orbs can be used to purchase Angels. Green Orbs are used to by Action Cards, and a combination of all 5 colors gets you a Gate Key.

On a players turn, they may choose to do one of the following actions: 1) pulling Orb Cards 2) spend Orb Cards 3) Attack a player

You obtain Spirit Points by: Purchasing Angels and Demons, going through Gates using Gate Keys and White Orbs, buying Action Cards (some of them are just Spirit Points), or Battling other players!

In a battle, the attacking player uses their Demon Cards and the defending player uses their Angel Cards. Each player starts with 10 hit points. Players take turns rolling dice to try and damage the other player. 5's and 6's are hits wile 1-4 miss. Angel and Demon Cards consist of either Battle Cards that last for the entire battle (i.e. Armored Angel - You cannot be hit by 5's) or Attack Cards that are played before a player rolls the dice (i.e. Fire Demon - On your next roll, 6'd hit for 2 damage). The first player to bring their opponent to zero Hit Points wins.

Finally, the Character Cards in the game all give slight advantages and manipulate all of the mechanics listed above!
Now...Bow your head, say your prayers, and prepare for Spiritual Warfare!
mechanics: Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Hand Management, Variable Player Powers

name: Korrigans: Paris est Ludique Promo
description:
Promo expansion or Korrigans given away at the 5000 first visitors of "Paris est Ludique" in June 2014.

Place the Orange Korrigan in the village. The player that have the bag can move it to the neighbouring field and look at the clover tokens.

The Orange Korrigan exists in 10 different flavors, corresponding to the 10 Korrigans from the base game (but colored orange).

name: 3Dimensional Chess
description:
A two player game played on 3 standard chess boards arranged vertically one above the other. The "light" squares are transparent to help see what pieces are where. Each player starts with 16 pieces on each board in almost the same setup as standard chess.

There is only one king and he starts in the normal position on the centre board. Kings, Queens and Bishops move as normal but extended into 3 dimensions. Knights move as normal and stay on the board they started on. Pawns and rooks move as normal but can also move levels. There are five new pieces, Prince (which replaces king on top and bottom boards), Princess, Abbey, Cannon and Galley, each having there own special movement rules. The object of the game is to take the king.

Based on by 3dchess program for GNU/Linux. This variant is played on three standard 8×8 boards, stacked vertically. The middle board features the standard pieces, while the following new pieces populate the other two boards:

Prince (King), Princess (Queen), Abbey (Bishop), Cannon (Knight), Galley (Rook)

The movements of various pieces have been modified to allow them to move across boards (for example the Cannon must move three spaces in one direction, two in a perpendicular direction and one in the remaining perpendicular).

This version was developed and produced in a plastic board game format by Mind Games Manufacturing Limited.

name: Druglord
description:
Druglord is a thematic war-game based on the history of Cartel's wars, with a strong commitment pro-legalization.

4-6 Players will impersonate and control the most powerful and dangerous Cartels in the world: Mafia, Yakuza, Triads, the Cartel of Medellín, the National Crime Syndicate and the Bratva (Russian Mafia). They'll have to distribute their forces all over the world, conquer the production places of drugs (for example: Colombia or Afghanistan) and the markets (cities like Los Angeles, Amsterdam or Tokio), organizing the flow of 4 kinds of substances that have different perks. This way players will gain soldiers that can be used to attack or defend; cooperation is acceptable, regulated and sometimes very useful. There are also cards to be drawn at each turn, inspired by historical or fictitious events related to the criminal world. They can have good or bad effects, and often there are choices to be made.

The goal is known at the beginning of the game, when each player draws a goal card (all different but balanced) that has to remain secret until the conditions of victory are fulfilled. There's also a semi-randomized countdown towards legalization: an event that in our point of view (and according to the ideas of many economists) would terminate the business of Cartels. When this happens (after 2-3 hours, according to the players' choices) the game is over and victory is assigned by points.

name: Jungle Heart
description:
The long, lost island of Jungle Heart has just been discovered. What mysteries lie beneath its shadowy canopies?

Monstrous animals!

Vicious tribes!

Malicious militants!

Deadly traps and hazards!

Ghosts and demons!

Yet beyond all of these obstacles lies crumbling temples brimming with gold, jewels, and priceless relics.

In Jungle Heart, you and your opponents take on the role of an investor in the 1940s, sending adventurers, scientists, big game hunters and other pulp standards to the jagged rock shores of Jungle Heart to find the clues necessary to tap into the unlimited wealth of the island.

Game play is simple:

1) Recruit and equip your adventuring party... then it's "off we go" to the island.

2) Use supply tokens to pay for actions while on the island.

3) When the supplies run dry, your adventurers return to the mainland to regroup and reequip.

4) Play a victory card to earn points.

Jungle Heart is the second game in development from Wine Key Games and is capable of bringing hours--nay! weeks of indepth play.

Are you prepared to visit Jungle Heart?

name: Schulbuben-Streiche
description:
Objective: be the first reaching space 57
- moving by turns -
simple 'Roll&Move' game; ending on a red marked space follow instructions glued into the lid.

note:
published before WWI; game theme follows the 'Max & Moritz' story from Wilhelm Busch
for more information see http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wilhelm_Busch

name: Districts
description:
English:
The King wants to know which of his battalions is the strongest and faithful. They will be tested and the best one, will become the royal guard and will get the king's favor.

Each battalion is composed by 5 soldiers, 3 swordsman, 1 squire and 1 knight.
Each soldier has a different force value and movement, so players would need to combine them adequately in order to conquest the king's districts and capture the enemy battalions.

On each turn, player has up 3 movements to be distributed on
his soldiers. It should move at least one soldier per turn.

The king will announce 3 districts to conquest and then, the battalions will enter into the citadel to conquest it. The first one to have presence in the 3 districts will be the winner. Capturing soldiers enemies can also give the victory, as once 3 solders from a battalion are capture, they loses the conquest.

Once the winner of a conquest is declared. He take the district card and there is a new announcement. Then, a new district card is placed on the board to start a new conquest round.

The battalion that gets first 3 conquests (3 district cards), will become the king’s royal guard.

Spanish:
El Rey quiere saber cual de sus batallones es el mas fuerte y leal. Estos serán sometidos a prueba para determinar quien es el mejor, quien se convertirá en la guardia real y tendrán el favor del rey.

Cada batallón esta compuesta por 5 soldados: 3 espadachines, 1 escudero y 1 caballero.
Cada soldado tiene un valor de fuerza y movimiento diferente, por lo que los jugadores tendrán que combinarlos adecuadamente a fin de conquistar los distritos y capturar los batallones enemigos.

En cada turno, los jugadores tendrán hasta 3 movimientos para distribuir entre sus soldados. Deberá mover al menos 1 soldado una vez.

El rey anunciará 3 distritos para conquistar y es cuando los batallones entraran en la ciudadela para conquistarlo. El primero en tener presencia en los 3 distritos será el ganador. Capturar soldados enemigos también podría dar la victoria, pues una vez 3 soldados de un batallón son capturados pierden la conquista.

Una vez el ganador de la conquista es declarado, el jugador guarda la carta de distrito y nuevo anuncio del rey tendrá lugar. Entonces se saca una nueva carta de distrito y comienza una nueva ronda de conquista.

El batallón que consiga primero los 3 conquistas (3 cartas de distritos) será nombrado nueva guardia real.
mechanics: Acting, Area Majority / Influence, Area Movement

name: VIENGA
description:
Vienga is a deck of cards that captures and simplifies the English language. Each depicts a letter, a number, and a clearly illustrated part of speech (noun, tense, adverb...) or sentence form. The back of the card has example sentences to show how each grammar point is used.

The Vienga cards can be used to play a variety of games. Simply use the cards to create equations, or words, or sentences. Vienga can be a challenging group game or a solo learning aid. The Vienga cards help you visualize sentence structures, recombine and replace words, and develop creative thinking. Challenging for native speakers and students with a good command of English wishing to improve their language skills.

name: Hutzli-Putz Die Reise ins Abenteuer
description:
Objective: be the first reaching space 135
- moving by turns -
Each player moves forward according die roll; ending on a red marked space follow instructions glued into the lid.
note:
Likely published during 1950s

name: Let's Go to College
description:
The Let's Go To College game employs a gambling technique, with chips, to allow players to complete courses as a freshman, a sophomore, a junior, and a senior. Prentice employed illustrators to produce bright graphics in his games and utilized high quality materials as well.

From the rules:

SETTING UP THE GAME. The playing board with the colored chart is placed in the center of the table. The playing cards are lined up with the four packs of picture cards, face up, on one side of the playing board. They should be in this order: Freshman, Sophomore, Junior and Senior. On the other side of the board the four packs of Fun, Sports, Re-Exam and Flunk cards should be placed with these words up. The chips are divided among the players so that each has an equal amount of l's, 2's, 3's, 5's and 10's.

PLAYING THE GAME. The player on the left of the host plays first As a Freshman entering I. O. U., he stands up each time he plays. If he fails to remember this, he must draw a Flunk card as a penalty, altnougn he does not miss his turn. He pays 5 chips, registration fee, to the business office. He then rolls the dice on the playing board as he tries to pass his first course. Only the dice which remain on the board alter rolling , may be counted, using only the top numbers. He multiplies the dice total by ten to find his grade for the course. After rolling the dice, the player proceeds all follows: If, after multiplying, his grade comes to 120: he must pay 2 chips to petty expense, on the playing board, placing the chips so they do not interfere with the chart. If his grade is 110, he must pay 1 chip. This means he has tried too hard to pass. In either case he rolls the dice again, right away. If his grade is 100, 90, 80 or 70, he can draw the top Freshman Course card and keep it. He also must take or put chips into petty expense as indicated opposite his grade on the chart. If there are not enough chips to take, he is out of luck, and can take only what is there. This happens quite frequently throughout the game. If his grade is 60, 50 or 40, he must place on playing board the indicated number of "put" chips. He then has his choice of drawing a Fun, Sport or Re-Exam card. He must read his card aloud and after fulfilling the duties, he returns it to the bottom of the same pack.
If his grade is 30, 20 or 10, he must place on playing board the indicated number of "put" chips. He then has to take a Flunk card and follow its instructions before returning it to bottom of pack. If both dice roll off the playing board he receives a zero, and must place 15 chips on the board and draw a Flunk card. As soon as a player has completed his turn, the next player on his left rolls the dice to obtain his grade for his first Freshman course, and so on. To pass Freshman year and become a Sophomore, a player must hold two Freshman Course cards. The first to finish Freshman year receives all chips in Petty Expense. As soon as each player finishes his first year he must pay 5 chips, registration fee for Sophomore year, to the business office. Sophomore year is the same as Freshman year, only players may now be seated while playing. Sophomores must have two Soph Course cards before becoming Juniors. The first to finish receives all chips in petty expense. As soon as players finish Sophomore year they pay 5 chips, registration fee for Junior year, to the business office. Junior year proceeds the same as Sophomore year. The first to finish receives all chips in petty expense. As soon as a player gets two Junior Course cards he must pay 5 chips, registration fee for Senior year, to the business office. Seniors must obtain the usual two Senior Course cards before graduation. The first to finish Senior year receives all chips petty expense and IMMEDIATELY the game is ended.

name: i.hate.everyone
description:
i.hate.everyone is a tasteless party card game, allegedly about social media attention whoring, but mostly about trying to make your friends laugh by coming up with the most hilariously atrocious phrase to fit the current question or fill-in-the-blank. Guaranteed* to provide hours of fun!**


Not an actual guarantee.
And/or shame.



Each round one player is the OP. The OP draws 3 Status Cards (which have questions or fill in the blanks) and picks one. Everyone then picks a Comment Card from their hand, and the players take turns reading their cards out. Cards can also have special effects ranging from drawing more cards to having to read it out in a funny accent. Once everyone's read, each player picks up a Like token and hands it to another player. Whenever you stop playing, whoever has the most Likes is the winner!

name: Museums: The Card Game
description:
In Museums: The Card Game you are a Museum Director trying to build the best museums with the most amount of items and the best visitors you can attract.

Each player will have a hand of cards. On your turn you have four options. You can (1) play a Museum cards, (2) play an Artifact card on Museums, (3) play a Visitor card, or (4) draw a card from the draw deck. You are limited to playing three actions per turn. The first two actions can be playing Museums and/or Artifact cards and the third action can be playing one Visitor card. If you choose not to play a card, you may draw a card instead. Likewise, if you choose not to play any cards you may draw three cards.

Museum cards are played first and then Artifact cards are played on top of Museum cards. The Artifact has to match the type of Museum it is played on. Visitor cards are played to score points. Once a Visitor card is played, for each artifact card with the same interests as the Visitor, all players score one point.

The goal of the game is to reach 20 points. The first to reach the goal is the winner.

name: Avant Europa: Liberté
description:
This game allows 2-4 players (2-6 with the Avant Garde expansion) to experience and survive the chaotic times of the French Revolution. This is the first of nine releases planned for a fun deck building that can all be connected to play as one game.

The Avant Europa series allows you to walk through important times in the history of France and other nations of Europe. Have your own shot at impacting history by making the choices that change it. Witness the events that shaped the national histories of that era, and try to survive them while building your own political Empire.

The Avant Europa - Liberte storyline represents the viewpoint of various small noble factions. Starting out with a small Commune you build up your connections and influences in Politics, Lands, Trade, Economics, Goods, and Military. The goal is to protect France from it's enemies (inside and out), but also to be the one player with the most Victory Points amassed at the end of the game. As your Empire of influence grows at some point you can end up commanding great influence and power across Revolutionary France.

Players begin with a standard deck of 8-10 cards - depending on if playing the basic, intermediate, or advanced rules. The game runs from 12 turns (basic) to 28 turns (full version), divided into turns called "Seasons". At the beginning of each Season players draw four cards into hand. Play continues in Rounds until all but the last player have used or played all of the cards in their hand. That player gets one last Round of play and the Season ends.

Each Season player initiative is important because being First Player to start a Season gives that player first go at available cards in the Commons to purchase. Like many deck-building games there is the typical 1-and-1 Round, where a player can play 1 Action and gets 1 additional choice (usually to Purchase cards from the Commons that get added to the owners discard - and thus eventually to the players hand).

In addition players can move cards to their Domain, which reflects their public face to the world. Cards in Domain are not discarded until used and can be played as if from hand. Many give special abilities and benefits that increase a players ability to response to other players actions, increase income generated by other cards, have special means of defense, etc. To add even more color to game play these Domains can come with Asset cards that are unique to the controlling player and provide political flavour of the times to expand the options of game play.

This game is a very diverse peek into the life and times of the people of the era's it represents. Actual historical personalities and figures of the Revolution are available as Allies, along with the actual historically political factions, organizations, and local government forces of the day.

Unique mechanics include the ability to Raise Funds that the player can add to their treasury to help purchase cards, make bribes, and pay off Tax collectors -- which were the common bane of public that lead to the Revolution. Other unique mechanics include the ability to place Bribes on cards in Commons area, the ability to Power Block some cards to prevent others from using or getting them. Players can engage in gathering Goods that can be sold on the open market for increased income. Players have the option of building up basic militia forces to protect themselves against common Bandits or foreign powers, or to use their military to defend against other players once the anger of the French Revolution and civil conflict goes into full swing.

Every card in the game has two or more uses, which is what makes provides the plethora of strategic choices and card combinations. The game promises no two play sessions of this game will be exactly the same, and it is easy to see why given the options. The game will certainly appeal to veteran card fans of games like L5R or Magic who appreciate the artistic details. It will also appeal to players who have played out their copies of Dominion and want something far more immensely real then Ascension or Thunderstone.

There are many roads to Victory, largely based on the acquisition of certain key cards of value -- especially getting control of Cities and Ports of France. This can be done many ways, through political underhanded activities, military force, or economic control. The person with the most Victory Points accumulated at games end determines the winner. However there are other ways to win the game outright, such as by getting three Historical Events into a players Domain.

The strategic depth of this unique deck-builder game surpasses anything you have played before. With over 16 core strategies that you can pursue in combination to arrive at final victory, you will find yourself playing multiple times to figure out your own preferred winning combo.

This release Avant Europa - Liberte covers the period of the early French Revolution (1789 - 1793). More expansions are planned to follow, including three covering the rise of Napoleon, and three that cover the early years of French settlement in North America. The truly historical fans will be able to play all the released expansions modules in sequence from start to finish if they wish. You will be able to relive French History from 1600 to 1815.

Available expansions for this game include Avant Europa - Nationale (Age of Sail)which includes the years of trade and exploration before the Revolution (1760-1788). There is also the Avant Garde expansion which is both a two player introduction to the AE Universe, but that also served as the 5 and 6 player expansion for the base "AE-Liberte" release.

Other releases for "Avant Britannia" and "Avant Hispania" are also planned.
mechanics: Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Open Drafting, Storytelling

name: Movie Mart
description:
Monopoly type game about the film industry.
Game play: player throws the dice and moves his pawn around the board the number of aquares indicated by the dice total. Landing on a studio, theater or story the player may buy it by paying the price indicated on the board etc..like in Monopoly.
The game ends whenever the Director's pack is exhausted; when all but one player is bankrupt; at any time by mutual agreement.

name: EXTRACTOR Word Game
description: The EXTRACTOR Word Game is inspired by Scrabble, but features a twist to make play more strategic: You can extract letters from words that are on the board, as long as removal of the letter(s) doesn't invalidate any words in play. Then those letters are yours to use!

name: Stock Exchange
description:
Each player is issued 4 celluloid markers each marked LONG on one side and SHORT on the other. They place them on the board on the 'PLACE ORDERS HERE' square for any of 12 different stocks. There are 10 squares above and below this square and rolling the 3 special bakelite dice will tell you which stocks change value and whether they go up or down. 2 of the dice contain the names of the 12 companies on the game board and a 3rd dice has 3 'UP' and 3' DOWN' values. Each roll will impact 2 companies and the UP/DOWN die will tell how much the value changes. The player moves his marker up or down according to the roll of the dice. When the marker get to the top or bottom of the board, you either win or lose depending on whether you chose LONG or SHORT for that stock. Each game session is to last 5 minutes (1 stock trading day).

from a 1929 Sales Brochure
- "A new game which brings all the thrills of the stock market into every home. Easy to learn, fascinating to play, with the greatest ready-made market that has ever greeted a piece of merchandise. The stock market is in everyone's mind and on everyone's tongue. Every day the newspapers give it additional publicity. The public imagination is already fired with the desire to play the market, and "STOCK EXCHANGE" will catch like wildfire."

Distributed by the EKKO COMPANY of Chicago, Ill
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Dice Rolling, Player Elimination, Stock Holding, Trading

name: Ski-Slalom
description:
The playing pieces are moved by a handheld magnet under the game board. The goal is to complete a prior arranged slalom course in the shortes time with the fewest mistakes.

This game was published in the 1950s.

name: Mor-Fun Stock Exchange Game
description:
In 1936, the Universal Games Company of St. Louis, Mo. published the Mor-Fun Stock Exchange game. It was a bit out of the ordinary as the game board was made of 1/4" thick pressed board stock and had a long heavy metal spinner that spun on bearings. The lowest cost 'Home Model' sold for $5, which was a lot for a game in the 1930s. By comparison, the very popular game of Monopoly retailed for $2.00.

There was no scrip or play money with the game, the only trading was done with stock shares. The players trade stocks; the amount traded and the profit is determined by spinning the metal spinner then throwing the dice.

Each player is assigned a player number and in turn is a 'buyer' and spins the indicator bar. The player whose number the indicator lands on is the 'seller'. The number of stock shares will be shown under the players number where the indicator stops. The 'seller' then rolls the dice to determine the amount of profit the 'buyer' must pay for the stock shares. Multiply the number thrown on the dice by the number of shares to be transacted equals the amount of shares the 'buyer' must pay the 'seller'.

In addition, there are 'Futures', Margins', and the 'Pit' where players may be required to put shares of stock that can subsequently be won by any player as described in the rules.

The player who acquires the most stock at the end of the game wins. A player who runs out of stocks is eliminated from the game and play continues to an agreed upon time.

There is no scrip or game money, all transactions are completed with shares of stock.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Dice Rolling, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Stock Holding, Trading

name: Escape from Fairyland
description:
When I woke up, I was trapped in a book. I was inside the kingdom of fairy tales! I had to act quickly, in cooperation with the friends I met there, to plan my escape from that world. However, only one person could make it out safely...

To start the game, each player is dealt 1 fairy tale "heroine card" (Cinderella, Snow White, etc.) and 1 "attendant card." Using the abilities listed on these cards, as well as other cards drawn throughout the game, players attempt to collect heart pieces, create a heart key, and escape from Fairyland together with their attendant before other players manage to do so. Remember, only one person can ESCAPE from FAIRYLAND!!!

name: Muß i' denn zum Städtle hinaus
description:
Objective: Be the first reaching space 61
- moving by turns -
Move forward according die roll; ending on a red marked space follow instructions glued into the lid. likely published 1938/39

name: To Be Emperor
description:
Three hundred years ago, the wandering tribe of Scragen settled at the shores of the Pentibar Sea. Over the decades, the settlement grew to be a great city and from it was born the thriving Empire of Vistos.

Today, Vistos faces a unique challenge. Astemaed, 12th Emperor of the greatest empire the world has ever seen, has died without an heir. By law, it falls on the senate to elect his successor. Very few candidates are worthy in the eyes of the senate. You are among them. Through strength, cunning and the power of your wealth, you must persuade the senate to your side and thwart your rivals' attempts to do the same.

No higher seat of power exists, no greater title than Emperor of Vistos. Who's coin shall ring the loudest? Who's might shall overcome? Who's knowledge shall prove greatest? The world watches and waits as you attempt... To Be Emperor.

To Be Emperor is a strategy card game of bidding and resource management. By winning bids on Assets, you gain the resources necessary to maintain Senators you have won to your side as well as to affect game play. By winning bids on Senators, you bring yourself closer to victory. The first player to have persuaded Senators to their side worth 10 or more Influence in the senate is the next Emperor of Vistos. Take care, though. Bid too greedily on senators or use up your resources with haste and you may find the Senators in your pocket seeking deeper pockets elsewhere.

In the files section are PDF and zip files with the rules and all the cards ready for print and play. You will only need to provide tokens (five per player, a different color for each player). All I ask is that you contact me with any constructive criticism and ideas, how many games you played, how many players and how long for each game.
categories: Card Game, Economic, Fantasy, Political, Print & Play

name: SpeeDeck
description:
SpeeDeck includes a set of cards, chips, cubes, and a stick. With these simple components you can play 5 different and unique games:

1. Chicken Run (2 players - 15min)
Each player is the driver of a car hurtling toward their opponent. Two cards are played from the players' hands each turn to determine the car mileage and position in a wall of fog. Without hitting, who can get the closest? Who will blink first?!?

2. Best Pitching (3-4 players - 30min)
In this speedy trick-taking game, players take on the role of a baseball pitcher attempting to win a game! The number of tricks which can be taken in a single round is determined in advance. Players compete for the specified number of rounds to get the most points.

3. Tumbling Dust (3 players - 15min)
Attempt to read the hands of the other players or you'll be at the mercy of the strong winds! Players can change the wind strength, direction, and movement of other players with the goal of collecting the most wind blown garbage.

4. Document Sort (2 players - 5min)
This is a real-time card sorting race between two players. Players compete to make a set arranged in numerical order before their opponent. Quick judgment and hand speed will be needed to win!

5. Parachute Dive (1 player - 10min)
Sky diving solitaire! Is it possible to land safely by controlling your rate of fall!? This game is played in two rounds. In round one, the player attempts to successfully deploy their parachute. In round two, the player has to land with their feet on the ground! Good luck!

name: Troglobites
description:
Fingertip Fungal Farming.

In Troglobites, players take on roles as mushroom gardeners in the deep dark cave. Every turn you rummage through the great rubbish heap, bringing home prize mushrooms (or perhaps nasty pests).

Each turn, you are offered 4 mushrooms pieces, picked blindly from the central heap by the previous player. You must choose three to keep and one to discard. Each type of mushroom/pest has a tastiness value, and a placement rule. You are trying to grow the tastiest mushroom garden.
After a player fills the central hexagon of their garden, the game enters the final round, ending when it returns to that player.

The pieces are deliberately textured, and the rules suggest that on the 2nd or 3rd game players should be blindfolded, relying on their fingertips to 'see'.

name: Cog Wars
description:
While Prof Von Neumann's Mechanikal Marvels may be much admired in academic circles, inside his lab it appears these clockwork amobeas are locked in a brutal struggle for survival!

This game is intended for small parties of up to 8, but the game achieves maximum cerebral satisfaction between a pair.

Each turn a player, gentlemen or lady, may place or move tiles that add to their amobea, strengthening, attacking or shielding it from the predations of others. If they were fortunate enough to have overlapped (and thus devoured) tiles of their opponent on the previous turn, their amobea's increased vitality is expressed by the placement (or movement) of extra tiles in this turn.

The game is simplicity itself, but brings to mind the mental challenge faced by two wrestlers of that delicate Oriental sport, Sumo.

name: The Space Merchant of Tamlore
description:
TRADER, MINER, BOUNTY HUNTER, EXPLORER, MANUFACTURER

Choose YOUR own destiny in a galaxy full of possibilities

In 2201 A.D., a routine asteroid mining mission went to the dark side of Saturn to seek out new sources of raw energy to power the massive metropolises of Earth and Mars. They arrived and discovered an ancient alien warp gate floating amongst the chunks of ice that made up the planets' rings. The leaders of Earth activated the gate and sent expeditions to find out what was on the other side. The explorers returned and told tales of new worlds to discover, colonise and exploit.

It is now 2265 A.D and with the aid of the warp gate, humanity has spread out across the galaxy.
You are the sole heir to the wealthy Star House of Tamlore. Your palace resides on a frozen world at the edge of the backwater kingdom of Galsia. You have lived a sheltered life knowing little of the wealth your father created by harvesting the Xerer’s asteroid fields that dominate the planets skyline, and trading the goods the colonies that you govern have created. In an instant, you are thrust into a Universe full of danger and intrigue where you and your loyal protector Fenrix, barely escape with your lives following a devastating attack on your home world by the insidious Star House Greaver.

Now completely alone, you must set out to rebuild what you have lost, and seek your revenge

By using innovative board game mechanics The Space Merchant of Tamlore is the next evolution of adventure gaming!

name: The House of George Walter Michaels
description:
From publisher blurb:



Can you escape from the House?While conversing with your associates, the distressed fiancé of your friend, Arthur Reginald, enters. Being long overdue for returning to her, she has become worried. It is uncovered that he planned on exploring the mysterious house of George Walter Michaels, an abandoned property surrounded by superstition and dark rumors, but when she expressed her worry about such an action, he lied that he would join you instead. At the brink of tears, she requests your assistance in locating him before something tragic can occur. You inform her that any ominous premonitions about her fiancé’s exploration of the house are unfounded, but agree to aid the lady none the less.

Upon entering the dilapidated building, you all are affronted by unimaginable horrors that threaten life and sanity. Can you find the right door out, the key to open it, and the means to survive until the break of day to be free from those what lurks in the house of George Walter Michaels?

As a 10 Die Survival Game, the players run through as a group, trying to survive the cards that remove their pile of Dice. If you are out of Dice, you are dead.

This is a game for 1 or more players. You need 10 six-sided dice per player to play, or if 10 dice per player is too much, you will need some way to track the dice that they have remaining – a pad of paper, some counters, etc. – and 10 dice.

The game also requires a deck of 10 Die Survival cards. This deck should normally be comprised of 3 Salvation cards, and at least half of the total deck should have Encounters (see below). A standard size for a deck is 30 cards.

Each player should begin the game with 10 six-sided dice; this represents their life/sanity/etc – when you have 0 dice remaining, you are out of the game.

When all 3 Salvation cards are found, then the game ends. All players that still have dice remaining can pat themselves on the back, while all dead players shouldn't feel too bad for dying to the difficult circumstances that they were thrust into.

name: The Tomb of the Damned Pharaoh
description:
From publisher blurb:



Those that slumber must eventually wakeA colleague of yours sent you a disturbing note, which ended with the words:

"There is no safety for me while I reside beneath the shadow of the pyramids. I pray that you soon meet me in person after receiving this letter. Otherwise you shall not see me again."

You rushed to his dig in the middle of the Egyptian desert, but you find his camp ransacked and empty. Clutching to the hope that survivors may have fled into the opened tomb nearby, you enter with your band only to become trapped by sandstorms. But you hear sounds coming from somewhere within the dark corridors of men long dead. Is it your colleague or something far worse? And can you eventually find your way back to the Entry Slab, slide it open with the Crowbar, and escape the Tomb of the Damned Pharaoh into Calm Skies once more?

As a 10 Die Survival Game, the players run through as a group, trying to survive the cards that remove their pile of Dice. If you are out of Dice, you are dead.

This expansion introduces new card types - Anxiety and Tool cards - while adding more abilities that pit players against each other in the hopes that they will be the ones to survive.

This is a game for 1 or more players. You need 10 six-sided dice per player to play, or if 10 dice per player is too much, you will need some way to track the dice that they have remaining – a pad of paper, some counters, etc. – and 10 dice.

The game also requires a deck of 10 Die Survival cards. This deck should normally be comprised of 3 Salvation cards, and at least half of the total deck should have Encounters (see below). A standard size for a deck is 30 cards.

Each player should begin the game with 10 six-sided dice; this represents their life/sanity/etc – when you have 0 dice remaining, you are out of the game.

When all 3 Salvation cards are found, then the game ends. All players that still have dice remaining can pat themselves on the back, while all dead players shouldn't feel too bad for dying to the difficult circumstances that they were thrust into.

name: The Abyss of the Lurid Cove
description:
From publisher blurb:



Can you Escape from the Island of Fog?The Flying Dutchman is supposed to be a portent of a ship's doom. Not long after witnessing the legendary ship sailing through the air, a terrible storm runs you aground on an island surrounded by fog. As you explore it, along with abundant amounts of exotic fruit and fish that any rich man would pay to dine upon, you begin encountering the locals: monstrous sea creatures; half-man, half-aquatic abominations; dead sailors. You must escape this once-thought paradise, especially since the island is sinking into the sea!

As a 10 Die Survival Game, the players run through as a group, trying to survive the cards that remove their pile of Dice. If you are out of Dice, you are dead.

This expansion strives to add a little more choice to a player's turn; 16 cards force you to either face an encounter immediately or introduce an effect that will make one or more encounters afterward become much worse; a variety of items also allow for one-time helpful effects.

This is a game for 1 or more players. You need 10 six-sided dice per player to play, or if 10 dice per player is too much, you will need some way to track the dice that they have remaining – a pad of paper, some counters, etc. – and 10 dice.

The game also requires a deck of 10 Die Survival cards. This deck should normally be comprised of 3 Salvation cards, and at least half of the total deck should have Encounters (see below). A standard size for a deck is 30 cards.

Each player should begin the game with 10 six-sided dice; this represents their life/sanity/etc – when you have 0 dice remaining, you are out of the game.

When all 3 Salvation cards are found, then the game ends. All players that still have dice remaining can pat themselves on the back, while all dead players shouldn't feel too bad for dying to the difficult circumstances that they were thrust into.

name: Operation Afghanistan: A Solitaire Game of the Soviet-Afghan War
description:
Operation Afghanistan is a solitaire game of Combat during the Soviet-Afghan War. The player assumes the role of a commander of combined forces in Afghanistan. As commander, you are responsible for securing your Area of Operations (AOR) by successfully conducting various military operations in order to locate and destroy the enemy. Although there are many units available to you, they may often times be limited to you by political, logistical or geographical obstacles.

GAME OBJECTIVE
The objective of Operation Afghanistan is to successfully complete a number of missions and destroy enemy forces in order to gain Victory Points (VP) for the Soviet Forces. The player can choose to play a short game (4 Missions), an average game (6 Missions), a long game (8 Missions) or a full Tour (12 Missions). Once all Missions have been resolved (successfully or not) the Player totals his VP and compares this with the Victory Determination Table to determine the level of success.

Operation Afghanistan contains many colorful Unit Counters. Soviet forces include Spetsnaz, Desantnik, MI-24 Hinds, MI-17 Hips, BTRs, BMPs, Automatic Grenade Launchers, Mortars, DsHKs, Leaders and Air Support. Afghan forces include Mujahedeen, CIA trained Mujahedeen, Recoilless Rifles, and Mortars.

OPERATION AFGHANISTAN may be purchased at http://www.berserkergames.net
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hexagon Grid, Open Drafting

name: Who am I? No. 1
description:
A group card game based on bible trivia made by Zondervan.

From the directions printed on the back of the deck:
"Two, readers, on taking the Old Testament cards and the other the New Testament cards, read alternately until someone in the group guesses from the hints given the identity of the character. The tow reader idea does away with the monotony of one voice being heard all the time. "
categories: Card Game, Party Game, Religious, Trivia

name: Hog Trivia
description:
Hog Trivia is a game that was created in 1987 and was part of a lawsuit brought on by Harley Davidson, Inc against the manufacture of the game "The Hog Farm". The lawsuit brought forth by Harley Davidson in 1997 stopped all sale and production of the game (even though so few had been produced already, as they were only for sale at "The Hog Farm") an appeal by the owner of the hog farm, Ronald GROTTANELLI, was partially overturned. it was found that The Hog Farm can use the term HOG, but cannot use it in conjunction with items such as this game, effectively ending this board games life span.

The goal of the game is to collect nine t-shirt pieces. At the start of each his turn, the player has to answer a question read from a question card. If he answers correctly, he gets to roll a die and move his pawn the indicated number of spaces forward. If he lands on a t-shirt space corresponding to a t-shirt piece that he does not yet have, he gains that piece.

In addition to the t-shirt spaces, there are penalty spaces which will have some drawback. Among the question cards, there are bonus questions. When a player correctly answers a bonus question, he automatically advances to the next t-shirt space corresponding to a piece he does not yet have.

When a player has all nine pieces and passes the start/finish space, he wins the game.

name: War & Seas
description: This page does not exist. You can edit this page to create it.

name: Greedocracy
description: You are the CEO of a multinational mega corporation with strong ties to the influential circles of politics. Manipulate the market and bribe government officials, invest in weapons and market tobacco to kids, set up sweat shops and use child workers, dump chemical waste in a nature reserve and support evil dictators to gain access to valuable natural resources – everything is ok as long as it gains you more Power, Prestige and Personal wealth than anyone else. Remember: there is no such thing as enough!
mechanics: Hand Management, Open Drafting, Set Collection, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Top-It! Grand Prix Game
description:
This is a card game using a mixture of 9 types of cards (Start Racing, Slow Trafic, Engine Blows Up, Pit Stop, New Tyres, Tyre burst and 5, 10 and 15 laps). The winner is the first person complete 100 laps by getting five 5 laps cards and three each of 10 and 15 laps cards onto the table in front of them ("the Tableaux")by legal means.
Each player is dealt a hand of 5 cards and a turn consists of drawing one card and either adding a card to his own or opponent's tableaux or discarding.
Lap cards can only be added if certain precursor cards have been laid previously and some of these can be canceled by other cards played onto them by opponents.

name: Du glaubst zu schieben und du wirst geschoben!
description: The players must get their meeple from space "Start" on the outher ring to space 100 in the center of the game board. The movement is determined by a die. On a space with an arrow the meeples advance to the next ring inward or have to return one ring outward. If a meeple gets on an occupied space, the other meeple must return to the lowest numbered space on the ring they're on. The first player to get his meeple on space 100 winns the game.
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Four Suits of War
description:
Four Suits of War (subtitle: A Swords & Sorcery Card Game) is a game involving a standard deck of playing cards and some six-sided dice. (The game only includes the rules pamphlet; cards and dice are not included.)

In this game, clubs and spades become armies, diamonds become spells, hearts become armor, and face cards are heroes and leaders. Luck of the draw and luck of the dice play a great part in the outcome of the game, but skill and strategy are an important aspect as well. A quick game for two or more players.

name: Champions of Fire Mountain
description:
In Champions of Fire Mountain, you represent one of four clans battling for supremacy in the Frankish Kingdom of 768 AD. Drawing upon the four elements across the land, you use their power to build a variety of medieval buildings to empower your army for battle. Once all opponents have been beaten in combat, the final victor is crowned Champion of Fire Mountain.

In Champions, each player begins with 5 Basic Lands and 5 Light Soldiers. In the center of the table, a random selection of Building cards, Treasures and Soldiers can be purchased and added to each player's decks during their turn. Through skilled planning, players amass more cards and use their armies to defeat all the opponents on the table.

Champions contains 342 cards, consisting of 20 Building Sets, 3 Soldier varieties, 3 Treasure options, 4 Basic Land piles and 12 Legendary Cards. Players chose 8 out of 20 Building Sets to create game variety and use their Soldiers to reduce their opponent's life score from 30 to 0.
mechanics: Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Hand Management, Open Drafting

name: Pony My Love
description:
This is the day of the great horse show! Our riders prepare theirs horses and stay focused despite unexpected competition and traps set by their opponents. A game of combinations and love which unites the rider and his horse will overcome all the trials!

In order to win you have to prepare your pony for the competition before others competitors. To do this, each player must collect the following cards in order: Halter, Pony, Grooming, Fillet, Saddle Pad, Saddle

The First Player to complete these six steps wins.


C'est le jour du grand concours équestre ! Nos cavalières doivent préparer leurs montures et rester concentrées malgré les imprévus de la compétition et les pièges tendus par leurs adversaires. Un jeu de combinaisons ou l'amour, qui uni la cavalière et sa monture, saura triompher de toutes les épreuves !

Pour gagner, il faut préparer son poney pour le concours avant les autres concurrents. Pour ce faire, chaque joueur doit collecter, dans l'ordre, les cartes suivantes : Licol, Poney, Pansage, Filet, Tapis, Selle.

Le premier joueur qui parvient à accomplir ces 6 étapes remporte la manche.

name: Misti'zzle Of La Fontaine
description:
Où se cache le Corbeau ?
Avec le Renard...
La Cigale va-t-elle retrouver sa fourmi ?

Animé par les personnages des célèbres Fables de La Fontaine, Misti’zzle est un jeu de cartes basé sur l’observation au graphisme adapté pour les enfants.

Le but du jeu est d’assembler un maximum de cartes par paire pour former des mini-scènes des Fables de La Fontaine, en évitant d’avoir en main à la fin de la partie, la carte Mistigri représentée par le Chat Botté du conte de Perrault.

Les mini-scènes s’assemblent ensemble à la manière d’un puzzle pour créer le Misti’zzle (un puzzle de 4 cartes de haut sur 10 cartes de large).

--

Each player organises and places all their existing pairs face up on the table. Then the youngest player begins by taking at random any card from the player to his left in the hope of matching a new pair. If he makes a pair with this new card, he places it face up on the table, and takes another card from the same player to his left. If not he keeps the card and the next player takes his turn and play continues thus, until there are no more pairs. Gradually as
the game progresses the players are able to assemble the Misti’zzle a tableau presenting images of the stories of Jean de La Fontaine.

name: Was kommt dazu
description:
Was kommt dazu (What's added now) is a tile laying game.

It consists of 72 square cardboard tiles, similar to the tiles of a memory game, and a rulebook. There are 6 tile series with different pictures. 3 series of 16 tiles each (steamboat, wonder machine, sun flower), 2 series of 9 tiles each (flowers of the spring, bird), 1 series of 6 tiles (helicopter). The basic idea is that one tile of each series has the least amount of small details, another one the greatest amount of details (like with or without doorknow depicted, a bee with or without wings etc.). These cards must be sorted according to the amount of details picted from least to most in ascending order. A check is possible by turing the tiles around. On each tile back is one half of an animal or thing - horse, train car etc. If the cards are in correct order those halves match.

The rulebook suggests 3 games:
1) Solo game: The solo player takes one or more tile series, shuffles them and must lay them in the correct order.
2) Group game: The short helicopter series is done away with. Each player gets one tile series (well shuffled). Players start to put their series in order. The first player to do this wins - if he did correctly. This can be done with one round or in several rounds. If rounds are played the player who finishes first and has his order correct he gets victory points equal to the number of tiles in the series plus 5 extra points. The other players get one victory point for each tile that is in correct order. For the next round the series are shuffled again and each player gets another series than before.
3) What is disappeared: A series is laid on the table in random order. The picture with the most details is laid in the middle. Players look out for the tile where just one little detail disappeared then the next one etc.

name: The Keeper Board Game
description:
Pits heroes and villains from classic novels against one another in a race to collect the Books of Power, and a battle for all mankind. In The Keeper Board Game you can join forces with Shay, his girlfriend Becky, Grandfather Nolan, or a cast of heroes from classic novels such as Peter Pan and Pinocchio.

OR

Work with the Master and his cast of the world's most infamous villains in a race to the Books of Power. When a book is collected you unlock one of the characters from that book to use in part two. Good unlocks good. Evil unlocks evil. For example if Shay were to reach the novel Dracula first he'd unlock Van Helsing! If the Master were to reach Dracula first he'd unlock Dracula. Once all of the books are collected, and their characters unlocked, part two begins.

Careful there are skirmishes along the way that may set you back! Play a Battle Point Card, and draw your enemy into battle. Loser loses a turn. Winner gets an extra chance to draw an unlock-able card. Weapons and characters are hidden within the deck. A chance at unlocking them makes drawing from the deck even more exciting.

In part two you take all of your unlocked characters and battle by rolling dice. Last man/woman/team standing wins!

name: Elmo's Zoo Ride
description:
Very simple spin and move game. Players have little Choo Choo Train pieces that move along a track through a zoo. Spaces are divided into (four) colours and Zoo Gates. If a player lands on a Zoo Gate, he or she draws an Animal Card. There are 32 cards with eight types of animal, but which animals a player has (or how many of each) has no effect on the game.

The player that has the most Animal Cards once all players have reached the end (back at Sesame Street) is the winner.

name: Raiders of The Lost Bitcoin
description:
Once upon a time, an enigma and a race's map for a new kind of web race.
One full year of mystery, call it an adventure, a quest or a race !
Raiders & miners sail right through the map, solve several enigma and dive into the web to discover the lost Bitcoin...

Remember everything you'll need is in the map ! I swear it on the hidden Bitcoin wallet.

But do you really want to win the Raider's of The Lost Bitcoin's Trophy ?

name: Taktiskt relief-krigsspel
description:
Tactical wargame designed for military training, played by two players or teams plus an umpire. The full game consists of a rulebook, 8 geomorphic map 1x1 meter boards with 3D terrain, and 1000 game pieces representing military units of company size and below.

This is a free wargame, meaning there are very few rules. Players on each side write orders on map sheets and the umpire then makes all decisions on what the outcomes are, falling back to roll dice when not sure about something.

name: Paper Football
description: Paper Football is a Print and Play dexterity game, where you and an opponent use your fingers to “kick” a paper ball around, over, or through obstacles, and into the other teams goal. You make your own custom obstacles using pieces cut from the components pages, and use two fingers to run around the field and kick the ball.

name: Black Sheep Gone Wild
description:
The Greatest and Worst 'Most likely to...' game you will ever play
The Rules:
1. Flip over a 'Most likely to...' card
2. On the count of 3, point to the person who's most likely to fit that description
3. The player chosen then flips over an ACTION card and has to follow the instructions
4. Once completed, that player flips over the next 'Most likely to...' card

Card Types:
There are 2 main types of cards: 'Most likely to...' cards and ACTION cards. Within the 'Most likely to...' category, there are 3 types of cards:
• ALL: All players can be chosen in this round
• GUYS: Only guys can be chosen in this round
• GIRLS: Only girls can be chosen in this round
Action Cards:
• ACTION: Player chosen has to follow the instructions
categories: Card Game, Humor, Mature / Adult, Party Game

name: Fenrir Unbound
description:
“According to Norse myth, Fenrir the wolf was the third son of Loki and the giantess Angrboda. It was prophesied that Fenrir would one day devour Odin ushering in Ragnarok. Tyr the god of war took it upon himself to feed Fenrir while he was still a pup, but as time went on Fenrir grew larger as did the gods' fear of him. The gods then decided to bind the wolf with a fetter they called Leyding. The wolf easily broke free of his bonds. The gods then used another fetter called Dromi and once again to no avail. Receiving word of this Odin called upon the dwarves of Svartalfheim to fashion a fetter made up of six magic ingredients, they called this ribbon-like material Gleipnir. Once bound with Gleipnir, Fenrir was unable to break free…”

Object of the game
The players “Viking gods” win if they manage to collect 3 of the 4 sets of Fetter tiles; otherwise the players lose if Fenrir reaches Odin first.

Components
1 Fenrir wolf figure

4 chips in four colors, 1-red, 1-blue, 1-green and 1-yellow

4 Viking god figures in four colors, 1-red, 1-blue, 1-green and 1-yellow

25 square tiles comprised of 1 Odin tile and 24 Fetter tiles in four colors, 6-red, 6-blue, 6-green and 6-yellow

1 draw bag

Setup
Pick a color you’d like to play as and place a chip in that color in front of yourself.

The chips color also corresponds to the color of the Viking god that you will move in the game.

The Odin tile is the start tile place this tile face up onto the table.

Then place all 24 fetter tiles into the draw bag and shuffle them; draw one tile at a time from the bag and form a path of face up adjacent tiles that lead away from the start tile.

Next place the four gods into the draw bag, draw a god from the bag placing one on every 5th tile along the path.

Lastly place the wolf figure onto the last tile of the path; the wolf figure should face the path looking towards the Odin tile.

Now you’re ready to play!

How to play
The youngest player starts.

A player on his turn must, following the movement rules…

• Move his piece either forwards or backwards along the path and ending the move on an empty tile not of his color or
• Move forwards or backwards along the path and collect a tile in his color.

After a player’s turn, he calls out who’s turn is next by player color only, although this is a co-operative game players are not to help each other by verbally coordinating there moves.

Tile collection
A player on his turn collects a tile in their color by landing on it with their piece. Tiles are not removed from the path but instead are flipped over and the god that last moved is placed on top.

The game ends when any three of the four sets of color tiles have been collected or when Fenrir reaches the Odin tile.

Movement
The gods can move in three possible ways:

• Walking
• Long jump
• Leapfrog

Walking

To walk, simply move your god to an empty adjacent tile.

Long jump

A god may long jump over another god or even the wolf.

• When performing a long jump you must land an equal distance after the jumped piece as at the start of the jump, so for example, if the piece doing the jumping is four spaces away from the piece you're jumping over, you must land four spaces away from the piece being jumped.

• You can only jump one god at the start of a long jump.

• Multiple long jumps in a single direction are allowed per turn.

Leapfrog

A god may leapfrog over another adjacent god or the wolf ending the jump on an empty tile immediately beyond the jumped piece.

Multiple leapfrog jumps in a single direction are allowed per turn.

Restrictions
No two gods may occupy the same tile nor may a god move onto a tile that the wolf is on.

The gods are also forbidden to leave the path.

Wolf movement

The wolf moves either two tiles forwards or one tile back along the path, but its movements are dictated by what the player’s actions are after a turn.

• If a player’s piece moves onto a tile that’s not in his color, the wolf moves two tiles forward.
• If a player’s piece moves onto a tile that’s in the players color, the wolf moves one tile back.

When Fenrir moves onto a tile occupied by a god the wolf takes his place and the god is moved to the start tile.
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Point to Point Movement, Set Collection

name: The Notorious Beer Game
description:
Adult board and beer drinking game.

From the rules: All players start at Home. Each player throws the dice, moves their piece, and follows the instructions in the box where they land. If you take a beer card, you must immediately carry out the task given on it, after which you place the card on the bottom of the deck. Each finger of beer that you drink (approx. 2cm) counts as one point. A Killer counts as five points if you empty the glass in one go, or three points if you take your time. If you ail a task, it will cost you five points. Leaving the table without the permission if the other players or beyond the scope of a task costs you ten points. The winner is the player with the highest score.

Box contents: playing board, dice, 4 beer pieces (beer caps), and 32 beer cards.
categories: Dice, Humor, Mature / Adult, Party Game

name: Motor Crash Melee
description:
From the back of the box:

...And there they go!
