You will build decks of creature, item and spell cards. You begin the game by building a deck of about 20 cards. Player tokens begin on zero, as well as the starting castle, on the board. Each player starts with 7 cards from the starter deck. You can do each of the following once per turn:

1. Take 2 cards from your deck, keep one, place the 2nd on the bottom of the draw deck.
2. Use 1 spell card.
3. Roll the dice to move your token on the board.
4. Perform and action, such as summoning creatures (up to their required land value).
5. Pay the toll to another player if you land on their space.
6. Discard down to 7 cards.

Just remember Draw, Roll, Play a card. When you land on an empty space, you will fill it with one of your creature cards. When you land on a space already occupied by an opponent, you pay a toll or play a creature to battle it. Prior to battle, player can equip their creatures with items.

The goal is to obtain the most land.
mechanics: Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: Jumpgate Armada
description:
Jumpgate Armada is a sci-fi themed action packed 2-4 player board game, where you control one of two federation called Alpha or Omega. Take control of your federation ships to perform assaults against your opponent while gathering a valuable resource called type 12 ore, collected by each player's mining ships.

Each player also plays jumpgate cards, where dangerous events can take place. Experience ships being pulled inside black holes, unknown parasites liquefying and absorbing a player's ship or evaporated by the mysteries monoliths. Don't blink your eyes or you will be struck by asteroids, comets and meteorites then destroyed!

Smile at your opponent by obtaining tracker beams, shield restorers, bonus attack modifiers and experience the power of a super nova penetrating every ship in play and disabling their shields to 50 % or destroying them!

Jumpgate Armada is full of excitement, twists, and turns. Offering memorable laughs with your friends and family. Where Anything can happen. So climb aboard, buckle up, and brace yourself for the many adventures Jumpgate Armada will take you to!

name: Before Scotland: 750 AD – Empires
description:
Set in 8th century Northern Britain, Before Scotland: 750 AD - Empires is an epic economy-based tactical-combat strategy game. It is historical in nature with a rich context and set of mechanics drawn from original sources.

The game begins in 750 AD and lets you play as one of four kingdoms who struggle for supremacy: the Angles, Britons, Gaels, or Picts. After choosing a Leader and Moral Cause that give special abilities to your kingdom, each player works through four seasons each year: planning, deployment, battle, and recovery. During planning season, you collect tax revenues, recruit troops, and identify battle targets. During deployment season, you muster Warbands, travel the environment, and scout the terrain. During battle season, you engage opponents in battle and resolve individual skirmishes. During recovery season, you pay maintenance, retreat units and reinforce adjacent territories.

Actions in each phase affect the outcome of the next phase. For example, by travelling the Environment and scouting the Terrain during deployment season; you will alter the engagements in battle season. The battle system requires each player to select up to 3 Warband Unit cards, from their hand, that face-off with competing kingdoms. After a simultaneous reveal, cards are resolved one-versus-one with additional Supply, Tactics, or Training cards from the Warband, and purchased during planning season, that are used to modify the encounter. Winning cards remain at the settlement. Losing cards are returned to the Kingdom Reserve and must be re-purchased to re-enter the game. The game ends after 5 (shorter), or 10 (longer), years of in-game play and the remaining player with the highest net-worth wins.

This game is targeted at the serious strategy gamer and it is an in-depth title that combines deck-building, a working economy and geographic constraints.
mechanics: Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Hand Management, Point to Point Movement, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Higamus Hogamus
description:
Higamus Hogamus is a card game where the players must match pairs of cards that combine to make compound words. Each player is dealt six cards. On their turn, they may either draw a card from the draw pile or take a card from another player's hand. They then look in their hand for any pairs that make words (such as "cow" and "boy") and lay them down. There are also "Higamus" and "Hogamus" cards depicting the titular pigs that are worth bonus points but must be announced when drawn (so other players can draw from their hands to try to steal the points) and Krazy Kat and Holy Cow cards that deduct points.

A round ends when either any player runs out of cards or a player holds both Higamus and Hogamus in his or her hand. Players score one point for each card they have laid down, five points each for Higamus or Hogamus and negative five points each for Holy Cow and Krazy Kat.

An alternate version of the game allows players to ask other players for specific cards and play either cards that form compound words or matching cards. In this version, Krazy Kat and Holy Cow are a match as are Higamus and Hogamus.

name: The Creditor's Deal
description:
The Creditor's Deal is a card game created by the Frandzel & Share law firm as a gift for their clients. The theme is building a portfolio of loans.

Each player is dealt seven cards, and the rest of the cards go into a draw pile. On their turns, players check their hands for completed loans (a loan card and matching collateral card, or these two plus a guaranty card for higher-value loans) and then lay the cards down face-down in their portfolio. They then either draw a card from the draw pile or take the top card from the face-up discard pile. If they have more than seven cards, they must now discard down to seven.

Other cards can help complete loans, take away money, steal card from other players, steal or protect completed loans or cause another player's loan to be auctioned.

The game ends when the draw pile is gone. Players add the value of all their completed loans and subtract regulatory or legal fee cards and any unplayed completed loans they hold. The player with the highest total wins.

name: Hooked on Spelling Card Game
description:
From the box:
"Practice spelling skills by creating words with Beginning and Ending game cards. The first player to play all ten cards wins."

Players are dealt ten cards each. Each card has either a beginning or ending of a word--generally 1-3 letters. The dealer turns over the top card of the draw deck. The first player must then make a word by adding either a beginning or end card, as appropriate. The next player may then either cover the beginning or ending of the played word with one of their own cards to make a new word. If a player is unable to play a card, he or she passes to the next player. If no player can make a new word, another card is drawn from the draw pile to replace the beginning or ending card and play resumes.

The first player to use all his or her card wins.
categories: Card Game, Children's Game, Educational, Word Game

name: Wizard Battle
description:
Wizard Battle is a competitive strategy game for two or more Wizards and one Wizard Overseer, who runs the game. Dominate other Wizards in the field of Wizard Battle through your magical and mental might! Battle takes place over a series of turns in which Wizards privately perform their actions, all the while engaging in secret diplomacy with one another; cunning and ruthlessness will get you everywhere. All consequences are described simultaneously by the Overseer, as every Wizard can watch their fate - good or bad - unfold. But it's not set in stone, as time manipulating magics allow diabolical flexibility. Ultimately, at the end of the Wizard Battle, the Wizard not yet blown to pieces or driven insane wins access to the Wish spell and the title of #1 Wizard!

Features:


Outwit your opponents for the title of #1 Wizard and access to the Wish spell.
Game-play completable in 30 to 60 minutes.
Easily playable anywhere, including online, because there are no physical pieces.
15 different spells to cast, plus the option to stab your opponents, or take a nap.
Time travel to previous turns to change your actions.
Diplomatic gameplay where you make or break alliances as you need.
Optional rules to mix things up further, including a multi-game Wizard Tournament.
Playable against Satan for the rights to your immortal soul.
categories: Abstract Strategy, Bluffing, Fantasy, Humor, Negotiation, Party Game, Political
mechanics: Action Queue, Simultaneous Action Selection, Team-Based Game

name: Math! Leave Them Kids Alone!
description:
This game helps kids learn math by engaging multiple learning styles (Social, Visual, Verbal/Auditory, and Logical/Mathematical) The game is won by collecting goal cards. Goal cards are won by using mathematical operators to join cards in a grid into other cards which are set aside as goal cards. The grid cards are revealed and re-hidden during the game, so there is a memory aspect as well.

The game can be played at multiple levels from early elementary (just learning addition and subtraction with two digit numbers) to teens who know multiplication and division well and are learning powers, roots, and the Fibonacci series. Using a timer (not provided), you can handicap the game so that adults can play against young children.

The game teaches both regular numbers (1, 2, 3...) as well as Roman numbers. All cards also use images of dice to help kids understand the connection between the abstract number and the quantity that it represents. This can help anyone struggling with math, but it is especially helpful for certain special needs students.

The game was designed by a group of kids aged 10-15 as part of their First Lego League research project. The game works well as a team game, if you have more than 6 players.
categories: Card Game, Children's Game, Educational, Math, Number

name: Super Desafio Cinema
description: A trivia game about movies and cinema. Use your knowledge and overcome this challenge. Contains 1 board, 4-pin, 180 cards, 1 instruction manual and 1 roulette.

name: The Blue Riband of the Atlantic
description:
Ship board game from 1936, patent 377613, created by BGL London.

Features all the main ships including: Queen Mary, Normandie, Rex, Bremen, Europa, Empress of Britain and a a mystery ship called 552.

An ancient mechanic nautical game with lights and a turntable.

From the box: "A thrilling game of change".

name: Mosh Pit: The Card Game
description:
Mosh Pit: The Card Game is the fast paced game of hardcore moshing action!

Each player takes the role of a Mosher slamming, skanking and stage diving around the pit trying to prove themselves the coolest!

All players start the game with a hand of 3 Mosh cards, 3 COOL counters & 3 BRUISE counters, they then take it in turns drawing Mosh cards and playing Mosh cards from their hands, each card effects the players in some way, increasing or decreasing the amount of COOL or BRUISE Counters the players have in front of them as well as other game changing effects.

After every player has taken a turn a random Event card is played that effects the game even more.

After every card n the Mosh card deck has been drawn the game ends, Every player counts the amount of BRUISE Counters in front of them and minuses it from the amount of COOL Counters, the player with the most COOL Counters after this the player with the most COOL Counters wins and is the coolest mosher in the pit!!
mechanics: Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Hand Management, Simulation

name: Sail to Jipang
description:
In this roll-and-move minigame, players start in Europe and have to roll dice to sail their ships around Africa and Asia to reach Japan. On each turn, the active player may choose to either 1) roll the dice, or 2) pass. If the player rolls the dice, they choose 1 result and place a chip on that die spot. If there is already a chip there, they cannot choose that rolled die number.

A) If the chosen rolled die shows 2-6, that is the player's movement value. Move the pawn forward; each step costs as much as the number in the space being moved to. Repeat until you cannot move further. B) If the chosen die shows 1, the player's next movement value will be doubled.

After finishing A or B, return to choosing 1 or 2 again.

The winner is the first player to reach Japan!


2 six-sided dice and player pawns are needed but not included with this postcard game.
mechanics: Push Your Luck, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Zone of AssassinZ
description:
Before the Darc Plague breached the heart of planet Evoria, long before the Evorian assassinz broke free to avenge it. The elite battled for control and claim to the Zone; the ethereal gateway to one's true chamber evolution. The Zone tested each assassinz; preparation, instincts and skills in Evo Chamber Combat! Can you master the 7 Evo Chamber Elements? Vio Power, Rogue Strength, Azu Spirti, Zol Nature, Darc Shadow, Exo Light and Syan Destiny! The game of Ancient Evo Chamber Combat is here! Fate rests in your hands, how will you evolve and assassinate the opposition?

Rules of Engagement
Primary objectives: Eliminate opposing assassinz with your arsenal deck in the acclaimed RPG/WAR/CCG Jan-Ken+ Battlecard Game. Hit and counter strike your way to the top, but miss and your arsenal will belocked inside the grave chamber; unless it's recovered with a counter ability, winner of the counter eanrs the right to reload all face-up cards on his/her battle chamber. The loser must send all face-up cards to their grace chamber. Hits and counter strikes also gains 1 Evo Shard per hit. Earn 12 Evo Shards in battle to evolve and perform a battle check. Earn one more hit/strike to claim victory with a battle checkmate!

Secondary objectives: Send all of your enemy's arsenal cards into their grave chamber or defeat them with 1 direct hit to a player's unarmed battle chamber when they are down to the last of their arsenal cards. Good luck, and may the Evo be with you, assassinz of the Zone!

name: Galactic Domination
description:
Galactic Domination is a conquest game where players compete to take over all the planets in the galaxy. The galaxy includes board arranged in a grid (e.g., 10 x 10) and planets placed randomly on the board.

Players purchase ships, create population, attach each other, or make alliances with non-player races.

The core mechanic of the game is supply chain management. The number of people represented by an unbroken chain of player pieces (e.g., meeples, ships, populated planets, etc.) contributes to an attack or defense value.

The game was created by two young girls, 11 and 7 in 2014, as a project assigned by their father in order to get them off of YouTube while on vacation.
categories: Civilization, Print & Play, Science Fiction, Space Exploration, Territory Building
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Enclosure, Grid Movement, Modular Board, Network and Route Building, Player Elimination

name: Imperium Chronicles: In Harm's Way Tactics
description:
In Harm's Way Tactics is a turn-based tactical combat game set in a science fantasy universe called the Imperium Chronicles. Up to five players choose from six different characters, each representing a class: Assassin, Duelist, Grunt, Medic, Officer, and Psi Mage. Each character class has at least ten abilities (powers) from which the player can pick up to five before each game.

The game includes at least three ways to play, including quick skirmishes, missions, or a campaign. Solo play is also supported.

(Disclaimer: Not affiliated with the In Harm's Way line of RPGs published by Flying Mice Games.)
categories: Dice, Miniatures, Print & Play, Science Fiction, Wargame
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Paper-and-Pencil

name: Ready for Weather
description:
What is today's weather? Is it rainy, snowy, windy, or sunny? Play this game and you will be ready for any weather!

This game appears to be a roll and move with a spinner for movement. The sub-title is "a matching game", and the board shows both articles of clothing and weather conditions.

name: Demigods Rising: Heroes of Humans
description:
This promo pack for Demigods Rising includes human heroes from the world of Argalla. It is fully compatible with the print and play version of the game.

Pack contains:
Weaponsmith
Crossbowman
Assassin
Priestess
Paladin
Knight
mechanics: Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Dice Rolling, Role Playing

name: Demigods Rising: Heroes of Elves
description:
This promo pack for Demigods Rising includes elven heroes from the world of Argalla. It is fully compatible with the print and play version of the game.

Pack contains:
Fire Elemental
Ice Elemental
Pegasus Knight
High Elder
Sentinel
Wind
Fairy
mechanics: Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Dice Rolling, Role Playing

name: Demigods Rising: Heroes of Dwarves
description:
This promo pack for Demigods Rising includes dwarven heroes from the world of Argalla. It is fully compatible with the print and play version of the game.

Pack contains:
Blacksmith
Alchemist
Guardian
Engineer
Charger
Gunner
mechanics: Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Dice Rolling, Role Playing

name: Demigods Rising: Heroes of Orcs
description:
This promo pack for Demigods Rising includes orc heroes from the world of Argalla. It is fully compatible with the print and play version of the game.

Pack contains:
Overlord
Black Wolf
Stoneskin
Trapper
Ogre
mechanics: Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Dice Rolling, Role Playing

name: Myrtille
description:
Myrtille is a co-operative game trying to raise awareness of environmental issues. Players will build and explore the small world of Myrtille and complete missions what can have some environmental impact.

The game is made of location card (river, house, beach, forest, garbage dump, shop…), colored pawns, objective cards (which indicates what pawns should go where), two dice (one with colors and one with numbers), and time cards.

Each player has one objective card and a few location cards. The four edges of each location cards have one of three colors.

At the start of the game, one location card is put on the table and will represent the board used by all the players. All colored pawns are placed on this card.

On its turn, a player rolls the two die, and uses only one of them.

If they choose the colored dice, then they add a location card to the board, that will thus get bigger and bigger. To do so, they have to place one of their location card next to a card already on the board such that both adjacent edges have the same color as the die. Also, if the new card is adjacent to more than one card, all adjacent edges must have the same color.

If they choose the numbered dice, then they can move one pawn using as many movement points as shown on the dice, each adjacent card using one movement point. They can only move a pawn whose color matches one of the pawn depicted on their objective card.

An objective card is complete when all pawns depicted on the objective card are on one location card matching the location of the objective card. The group as a whole earns the victory points printed on the objective card.

The game has a limited number of turn, which is tracked using the time cards.
mechanics: Area Movement, Cooperative Game, Modular Board, Point to Point Movement

name: Juris Perjurious
description: In Juris Perjurious, players are wealthy Roman citizens who have gathered at the city forum to discuss new laws. Players are dealt a hidden support card representing an influential citizen who supports their claims. Your goal is to be the first player to collect 11 coins and get your new law approved. Each turn you may trade away your support card or use individual support card powers. Using the ability of a support card is the only way to collect coins needed for victory. Players will claim they have support of various citizens to gain coins, look at other player's cards or they may trade coins or cards, it will be up to all players to decide who may be bluffing. Players can only be stopped by making a public challenge of their support. If you are wrong a small fine is paid to the city Quaestor.
mechanics: Memory, Push Your Luck, Storytelling, Take That, Variable Player Powers

name: Kogeneracja
description:
Kogenercja is a game created per request of PGNiG SA - the largest Polish oil and gas exploration and production company.

The players compete in order to create the most efficient thermal-electric power plant. To improve their business, they gather resources needed for the growth of such company and building a power plant. In this game knowledge is as important as an understanding of economy, as players have to answer quiz-type questions in order to advance in the game.

As a game for the entire family, Kogeneracja promotes knowledge about the ways of producing energy and how power plants work.

name: Omkapp i luften
description:
Typical roll-and-move game on the theme "airplane racing". Roll one die, and at landing on certain fields the player must for example move back or forwards or sit one round out. First to land on field #60 is the winner. If you bet money on the planes, the winner get 2/3 of the cash pool; second get the rest.
The game is in Norwegian, probably printed in the late 1920s or early 1930s.

name: Moderne kappestrid
description:
This is the Norwegian edition of Moderner Wettkampf.

Typical roll-and-move game on the theme "modern racing". You must chose to be either a runner, an automobile driver or an airplane pilot. Roll one die, and at landing on certain fields the player must for example move back or forwards or sit one round out. First to land on field #40 is the winner. If you bet money, the winner get 2/3 of the cash pool; second get the rest.
The game is in Norwegian, probably printed in the late 1920s or early 1930s.

name: Fottball
description:
Typical roll-and-move game on the theme "Association football". Roll one die, and at landing on certain fields the player must for example move backwards or forwards or sit one round out. First to land on field #50 (#65 in the german version) is the winner.
The game is in Norwegian/Danish, probably printed in the late 1920s. The title is misspelled "Fottball" instead of "Fotball". Also, the label "Amuso" is printed on the box cover. The german version is called "Fussball".
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: The Global Diversity Game for International Relief and Development Organizations
description:
From the rulebook:
The Global Diversity Game for International Relief and Development Organizations is a highly interactive training tool using a multiple-choice quiz format to explore facts about global diversity.

Game play:
The objective of the game is to be the first to reach the center square of the board, and answer a question correctly to win. Players start on the "Go" square and roll dice to move around the track. On each space where they land, they must answer a question from one of six decks, all of which focus on some aspect of global diversity. A correct answer earns the player a colored chip. Tow chips of any one color may be traded for a single chip of any other color. When they have all outer track chips, players may move into the inner track. The first player to reach the center space and answer a question chosen by the team to their left wins.

name: Finger Bomb
description:
What can we do with just 6 numbers—0, 1, 2, 3, 4 and 5? Anything and everything! That’s the beauty and mystery of numbers. And this amazing possibility is beautifully captured in Finger Bomb™!

What makes Finger Bomb™ truly amazing is that it has taken just these 6 numbers and created an amazing array of 50 things we can do with them:

10 FUNtastic games
15 hands-on lessons
13 investigative activities
12 brain-boosting puzzles

Finger Bomb™ is a card deck system. It is part of a package that includes a card deck and a companion book. It is primarily designed for use in learning mathematics. It is most suitable for kids aged 5 - 8.
categories: Card Game, Children's Game, Educational, Game System, Math, Number
mechanics: Hand Management, Push Your Luck, Rock-Paper-Scissors, Set Collection

name: Hornet Hoops (2nd Ed)
description: This basketball game starts like the real thing, with a "jump ball" to determine starting player. From your hand and the two decks, two players go head to head placing players on their basketball team and defining the offense and defense. First draw from the player deck and play a card, then draw from the coaches deck and play a card each turn. Player cards will only score for you if they are played in the right positions on the court. This results in free-throws, jump-shots or 3 pointers. The coaches deck helps you pick which offense or defense both teams are using. Use the REF card to remove your opponents key player just before the quarter ends. With this simple 2 deck card game, you can re-create four quarters of a basketball game.
mechanics: Hand Management, Open Drafting, Simulation, Take That

name: Siege of Love: The Lady Matsu Hime Razan Summer Affair
description:
THE TIME IS: 1200 hours, 3 June 1615. The Shogun finally senses the approach of the end of a long term conflict. Toyotomi house still does not submit to the Shogun’s will.

Prologue
Father Ieyasu had it all thought out - clean up things at Osaka quickly to have a summer saké party with luscious Lady Matsu hime Razan at 1800 hours. The plan is set. Ieyasu had also interests in martial arts, tea, and foreign intercourse.

Osaka Battlefield 1000 hours.
Ieyasu: Ohhhh, Lady Razan!
Lady Razan: Oh! Tokugawa-sama!
Ieyasu: You’ve managed to come to the battlefield! May I know why?
Lady Razan: Oh! Yes, Oh! You naughty naughty Tokugawa! I’m your living reminder of our summer saké party …Oh! You’re even worse than Hidetada…
Ieyasu: Please leave at once! This is a dangerous place for a delicatessen as you. And don’t worry… I’ve instructed the Generals in our war council. I’ve explained them the notions of priorities and timings…
Lady Razan: OK! mumbo-jumbo-sama! 1800 hours, not a minute more… You have been warned!
Old man that was passing by chance, whispering, through the battlefield: And so it was. Everyone was at bliss, at least at Tokugawa’s mighty army. The low rank soldiers were partying since 0600 hours. Generals were laughing, confident and very moody about the upcoming battle. Ieyasu’s son, the Shogun Tokugawa Hidetada, began to move his full army in four parallel lines, prepared to make flanking maneuvers of their own. Oh yes I know… Richard Wilhelm already told that “The way to study the past is not to confine oneself to mere knowledge of history but, through application of this knowledge, to give actuality to the past”.

Osaka Main Castle 1130 hours.
A Toyotomi ninja reported Ieyasu’s plan. He was aware that Lady Razan would be somewhere in the battlefield… If somehow they could resist until 1800 hours… a last samurai plot was in forge…
Ninja: Grand Massster Toyotomi-sssama I wasss near master’sss SSSanada army and I wasss able to sssee it with my own armsss, hear with my own hair and sssmelling with my own fingersss ninja.
Hideyori: I knew it! That cheap sl*t! And are you aware of why I knew?
Ninja: sss no Massster Toyotomi-sssama ninja.
Hideyori: A long time ago, around two solar calendar years, I had a close relation with Lady Razan based on a conspiring plot against the old man Ieyasu, Shogun at that time… But that was before I decked in love for her…
The in meanwhile old man was passing through Osaka castle, whispering: Toyotomi immediately issued a hammer-and-anvil operation, in which his strongest core would attack the center of the Tokugawa Army, while a second force, would flank them from the rear to scare Lady Razan out of the battlefield. History tells that “…legendary swordsman Miyamoto Musashi participated in the battle on the Tokugawa Army side, though there is no recorded documental base in this battle…”.

THE TIME IS: 1200 hours, 3 June 1615.
A 0001 hour comical and competitive 2 player Super Postcard Game.
categories: Card Game, Humor, Print & Play, Wargame
mechanics: Action Queue, Area Movement, Area-Impulse, Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Hand Management, Role Playing, Secret Unit Deployment, Simulation, Storytelling, Turn Order: Time Track

name: 3D Connect
description:
This is a two player game played with a skeletonal 5 by 5 unit cube.

Each player starts with eight 2 by 1 pieces, either black or white, which can be neatly but firmly slid inside the holes in the cube in any of the three dimensions.

The object of the game is to be the first player to connect any two opposite faces of the cube with pieces of their colour such that each link is at least a 1x1 area.

Players take it in turn adding a piece and if no one completes a chain after all 16 pieces have been added, the game is a draw.

name: Roll a' Lantern
description: Roll a’ Lantern is a real time dice rolling affair where players rapidly roll their dice to trying to match the faces of the die to the Jack o’ Lantern card in play. When a player matches the dice faces to the current card in play, they yell out Jack o' Lantern and claim that card. The player with the most Jack o' Lantern cards claimed when the deck runs out is declared the winner.

name: Double Trouble Cubes
description:
A Dice 10,000-like game using Backgammon doubling cubes.
A simple solution is included for those who do not have any doubling cubes.
The same general rules and ideas apply, but scoring has been considerably changed by the fact of using doubling cubes instead of dice.
The individual digits of a number on the face of the cubes come into play.
Reimplements "Dice 10,000" but adds some twists only possible with doubling cubes.

name: Pounce
description: Pounce is a fast paced dexterity game for 2-8 players that can be played as either individuals or in teams. Throughout the game small cups move around the table and players attempt to bounce a ball into the cup in front of them. If the player on your right completes this task before you, they can stack their cup on top of yours. The stacked player has to take a tower penalty shot – potentially losing one of their lives and suffering a temporary handicap. The game ends when only one player or team has lives remaining.

name: Space Perimeter
description:
Space Perimeter is a game where companies (players) explore space by playing square cards in their hand to form the playing board. Cards will have a numerical value on each side. Once a card has been placed, players will add up the total value on the side of the map facing them. This value, or Acclaim, will fluctuate during the course of the game.

Players can use Acclaim to build Space Stations, deploy Spy Probes, or colonize Planets. The goal of the game is to have the highest Acclaim after the last card is drawn.

name: Tarot's Kingdom: The Guardians of Destiny
description:
Kingdom's Tarot: The Guardians of Destiny is a card game that allows the player to control one of the Lords of Tarot clans, these clans have similarity with the suits of the conventional deck.

The goal of each clan in that realm is to influence the maximum amount of souls possible, because it is the divine mission attributed to these clans. Of course, every soul has a different value. Each more valuable souls obtained, these lords will be send to the higher plane.

The game can be played 2-4 players, each one will control a Lord of one of the clans, the clans have its own characteristics to play the game.

Each player uses a book that contains several cards that will change the game, with conditions, influence and destination cards. These cards will affect the souls of the board directly.
In the setup, before beginning of the first round, there will be a draft among the players to get the Majors Arcana Cards, these cards change instantly or permanently the conditions of the game.

Each round 5 new souls will be revealed in "Souls Nursery" in this place players will be able to see who offers to influence souls when the soul is with an established influence it will incarnate.

On earth the soul will pass to three phases, past, present and future.

The game ends after the first player intended seven souls, the one who gets the most soul points wins.

name: Secret Words
description:
Secret Words is the game show style word guessing party game for 4 or more players. Try your best to get your teammate to guess the Secret Words on your card, but there is just one catch: you can only use a single word. Knowing how your teammate thinks is the key to winning. Each team has only 60 seconds to guess as many words as they can. If any of the core rules are broken you

There are 4 core rules to Secret Words.

1. Any clues given must only be a single word.
2. The clue must not form a part of the Secret Word.
3. No physical hints may be given. (e.g. gesturing or pointing to something)
4. Only one clue per guess. (You must wait until teammate has made a guess)

name: Sneaky Conversations
description: Sneaky Conversations allows you to creatively exercise your vocabulary, while having fun! The game is played by trying to sneak a word or phrase into a conversation without being challenged or without having the word or phrase guessed correctly after being challenged. Players will have one or more Sneak Cards in their hands with a word or phrase on each one. We provide the word or phrase, you sneak it into the conversational statements you make.
categories: Bluffing, Card Game, Humor, Party Game

name: STOMP-EDE!
description:
STOMP-EDE! is a dinosaur themed trick taking game. The dinosaurs used in the game were picked from familiar and popular dinosaurs that most everyone knows about. The main goal of the game is to have the most points at the end of the round.

The game is broken down into four suits: Green, Blue, Purple, and Orange. Green cards are essentially the trump or the most powerful cards. The player to the right of the dealer goes first, often times they want to play cards with less power to get a good idea of the strength in everyone else's hand.

The player who took the previous trick then plays, or "leads," a new card for the second trick. After all tricks have been taken, their point values are totaled and the winner declared.

name: BrainBites: Myths & Legends
description:
Be the first to fill your brain with brain cells in this game for all the family!
In this quirky quiz each card refers to a famous myth or legend. There are three questions per card worth either 1, 2 or 3 brain cells. You choose the level of difficulty and the correct answer fills your brain card with either 1, 2 or 3 brain cells.
The first to fill their brain card is the winner!

name: Disney Pop-Up Magic Enchanted Mini Game Featuring Jasmine
description:
From the publisher:

"Be your favorite princess in this dancing Pop-Up Magic Enchanted Mini game! The gameboard for this Disney-themed game has a pop-up ballroom in the middle. Just set your Jasmine princess figure at Start on the board, and dance her ahead on the board as you flip over Friend Tokens! Watch out for the Villain Token, because it sets you back a space. You can use your Friend Tokens with other Pop-Up Magic games (sold separately) for even more magical fun. If you reach the enchanted ballroom first, you win!"

You can add Jasmine to any Disney Magic Pop-Up board game.
categories: Children's Game, Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Patient Zero: A Solo Epidemic
description:
You are a lead Doctor with the CDC, specializing in Pathogens and Contagious Disease, top in your field. You and your team of highly trained Specialists are tasked to determine the source of a new deadly, highly contagious disease. They have discovered the original carrier who has transmitted the disease to countless others and brought him to you. You have only three days to keep Patient Zero alive and discover a successful treatment before it becomes a worldwide pandemic and all is lost.

The gameplay is simple:
There are 4 Disease types infecting Patient Zero.

Virus
Bacteria
Fungus
Parasite


Patient Zero consists of 6 cards: Head, Torso, 2 Arms, & 2 Legs.
There is one single deck containing "Positive, Negative, and Neutral Effect" cards in 4 colors representing the 4 types of Diseases.

Once you flip cards to determine starting Disease Types...
The turn order is broken up into 3 Phases:
1. INFECTION
2. RESEARCH
3. TREATMENT

Gameplay is broken up into 3 "Days" being the number of times you cycle through the deck. If Patient Zero survives the end of Day 3, you then add your points based on how well your treatment was. If your score is over 100, you lose, treatment was a failure. If under 100, you win! Your treatment was successful and you can start manufacturing a cure! You saved the world!

name: Etiga Tagasi Olevikku!
description:
Promotional game for Tallinn Broadcast Tower.

Their mascot Eti travel through the game board and players try to find him back to the tower by rolling the die. The player who finishes first is the winner. There are also cards who can add or substracts the die-pips.

name: Lobster and Turtle
description:
Lobster and Turtle is a simple game with two custom d6 dice. One die represents the "lobster" and replaces the single pip face with an image of a lobster. The other represents the "turtle" and replaces the single pip face with an image of a turtle.

This is a straightforward press your luck game. On your turn, you roll the two dice, note the point total, and you have the option to roll both dice again to attempt to add more points to your turn's total. You can choose to stop after any roll and add your points to the turn to your overall game's total. However, if you roll a "lobster" or a "turtle," you lose all points for the turn and your turn ends. One final twist: if you roll both a "lobster" and a "turtle," you immediately add 50 points to your turn's score, you add your turn's score to your overall total, and your turn immediately ends. The first player to 200 points is the winnter.

name: Gazociągi: Gra o inwestycje
description:
This game has been created by the request of Gas Transmission Operator GAZ-SYSTEM S.A., a strategic company for Poland’s economy and energy security. In the game, the players's task is to create gasline connections. To do it, they will have to answer questions about the gas industry - each question they answer correctly becomes a resource which can be used to create a part of the connection.

The player who gains the most victory points from creating the randomly drawn connections between cities (a'la Ticket to Ride) after the Tanker marker reaches its destination twice, wins the game.

name: Geh mit mir!
description: The players start with one meeple at space 1 and have to get to space 75. Movement is deterined by die. On their way, the players try to collect the 3 other meeples of their color, which the have placed on any three spaces on the board before the beginning of the game. The first player to reach space 75 wins the game. Second place goes to the player who collects the most meeples.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Pick-up and Deliver, Race, Roll / Spin and Move, Track Movement

name: Tõeline Eestlane
description:
The Real Estonian in English is a reimplementation of Raamat.

Each player has their own character: Politician, Doctor, Teacher, Businessman, Celebrity etc. who move through the book. Sometime there is a questions about Estonia - if you answer correctly you advance by turning the pages, sometime funny surprise what may help you advance or bring you back.

Player who reaches first to the end of the book is the winner.

name: Purple Heart
description:
This product is compatible with Advanced Squad Leader. It features 4 new scenarios and 2 new boards. The boards are winter boards with white being the color of open ground. All the scenarios are set during the Battle of the Bulge in December 1944.

Cemetery Stand features action at Stoumont as Peiper tries to push the Americans out of the village.

A Town by any Other Name depicts a German armored attack against a mixture of rear area US troops near Ligneuville.

East of Trois-Ponts models the efforts of the German SS to reopen the supply line to Peiper's troops.

Foggy Notions is another scenario where the Germans are trying to reopen supply lines to Peiper's troops.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Wargame, World War II
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hexagon Grid, Modular Board, Secret Unit Deployment, Simulation

name: Corpocracy Board Game
description: A politically INcorrect game about workplace antics. 2-6 players compete with eachother to overcome pitfalls and reap rewards as they work their way up the corporate ladders. The first player to reach the top wins the game and gets to kick the CEO's butt out of the Ivory Tower!
mechanics: Role Playing, Roll / Spin and Move

name: qubri
description:
qubri is a memory game played with 48 wooden tokens in six different colors.

Initially the tokens are placed in sixteen stacks three tokens high in a 4x4 grid. On a turn, a player rolls two color dice. They have to use one die to move one token on top of a tile showing the color indicated by the die. Then they try to reveal the color indicated by the other die by removing one tile. If the revealed tile shows the right color, you can keep the tile you removed.

The player who gets the most tiles of a single color wins.

name: Flags of Valour: Eastern Front
description:
“Flags of Valour” is a toolkit system for war game enhancement. This particular release is Set 1, and deals with the German, Russian, and Finland forces of the Eastern Front.

FOV is a set of modules that extend the use of any counter based war game so that you can add both the often under-utilized practice of “Fog of War” OR that of higher level Intelligence Gathering and Logistics to virtually any simulation game. The game tool is also used to represent hidden assets such as Ammunition Supply, Fuel, and other factors common to any higher level logistic advantages gained via logistical planning. It is in fact this "Level Over" that FOV uses to bring new strategies and tactics to most war games without changing the underlying game rules. The level of added realism this tool set provides is rarely found in conjunction with any other current game publication.

What the Flags of Valour systems all do is give players of wargames a way to remove most of your counters from the board at the start of any game, and replace them with national hidden placement counters. Meantime you have a hidden area where normal game counters are kept on LUC (Logistical Unit Cards) until enemy recon or proximity force the regular unit pieces to be placed on the board and revealed. This allows war games to start with a form of hidden movement and place that is traditionally thought of as “double blind” play. Except in this case you can do the double-blind with only one central board (unlike the awkward and messy way that most double blind games take up a lot of room and require two copies of a board or a game).

Depending on the particular FOV release, some provide for additional hidden rules such as Strongpoints, Air Strikes, Guerilla activity, Supply Lines, and more. Add on rules are completely optional, and are left to the discretionary use of the players using the system.

Each FOV release comes with 2-6 nation state counters. There are releases for many different eras available, but primarily the counter sets cover WW2 and Modern use. There are also the “125” series of FOV releases for use with Miniatures games. Those use larger placement counters and much larger LUC (Logistical Unit Cards) on which to place miniatures hidden off the board.
categories: Abstract Strategy, Miniatures, Modern Warfare, World War II

name: FreeSpace Tactics
description:
FreeSpace: Tactics is the official licensed miniatures game for two or more players based on the FreeSpace video games from Interplay. The core set includes four different ships (Apollo, Valkyrie, Anubis and Horus) from the series.

FreeSpace: Tactics uses cards for movement and combat. During set up, players customize their movement decks with a number of Ace cards based on their ship types.

At the start of each turn, players simultaneously select one card from their hand for each ship. Cards are revealed in initiative order and that ship moves and attacks.

The combat system uses d6, d8 and d10 dice - the exact pool comes from the attacker ship type and card used. Damage reduces shields and inflicts hull damage. Missiles roll a special die and may deal critical hits.

Six scenarios come in the core set, and there are guidelines for expanding those scenarios or creating your own.

name: Pirates Melee
description:
The pirate with the most jewels wins this head-to-head game. Players must move their colored pieces around the board attempting to capture opponents 10 pieces and the five jewels which occupy the board. Players depart either hidden or safe harbour at the start, and

To do so the players move their pieces one or two spaces per turn in any one direction and attempt to land atop an occupied space, capturing either the pirate piece of an opponent or a jewel which resided there.

Captured pieces are removed from the board, and a player wins if he or she removes all of the pieces belonging to an opponent. Otherwise, play ends when all of the jewels have been claimed, and the player with the most jewels wins.

name: Chopper War: A Solitaire Game of Helicopter Combat in Vietnam
description:
CHOPPER WAR is a solitaire game of Helicopter Combat in Vietnam. The player assumes the role of a commander of an Air Cavalry Troop consisting of Gunships, Scout Ships and Lift Ships, plus, a platoon of Aero-Rifles. As commander, you are responsible for securing your Area of Operations (AOR) by successfully locating, fixing and destroying the enemy. Your mission is to destroy as many enemy units with the minimum amount of losses to your Troop.

GAME OBJECTIVE
The objective of CHOPPER WAR is to successfully complete a number of missions and destroy enemy forces in order to gain Victory Points (VP) for the US Forces. The player can choose to play a short game (4 Missions), an average game (6 Missions), a long game (8 Missions) or a full Tour (12 Missions). Once all Missions have been resolved (successfully or not) the Player totals his VP and compares this with the Victory Determination Table to determine the level of success.

Units include Huey Slicks, Huey Gunships, AH-1 Cobra Gunships, OH-6 Scout Helicopters, Aero-Rifle Squads (the Blues), and Special Forces Teams. Missions include Hunter-Killer Teams where a Scout and Gunship attempt to locate and destroy the enemy, Hawk Flights in search of VC/NVA Suspects, Rescues of Downed Crews, Fire Support, Firebase Overrun Support and Search and Destroy operations with the Aero-Rifle Platoons.
mechanics: Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Dice Rolling, Hexagon Grid

name: Dangerous Adventure
description:
Dangerous Adventure is a game where players have to complete quests (killing monsters, farming components...) to gain the best amount of Victory Points.

The players must create greats armors, train powerfull powers or buy differents items making their task more easy.

There are multiples actions to do. These actions have a cost in hours, and players must to manage these hours on a big clock that determines the turn order.

Finally, the different kinds of monsters will make players gain experience in combat, may face increasingly difficult challenges

name: Colossi
description:
Overview

A deluge of large, mysterious meteors have fallen from the sky and struck the lands of Astralevia. Each meteor contained a monstrous, rock colossus that has come forth from its crater, hellbent on devastating the land.

As dire as a threat these Colossi pose, more than a fight for survival emerged once the rare and powerful Cosmic Ores that compose their bodies were discovered. These special ores are capable of producing weapons and tools of uncanny properties. And so, those guided by greed, power, new order, and even peace (to keep this commodity out of the wrong hands) have quickly assembled bands of warrior-miners to harvest this extremely valuable resource from the Colossi. These warrior-miners—known as Veinreapers for their ability to crack apart the Colossi through their rich veins of ore—have been equipped with special Pickaxes forged from Metal Shards scattered by the meteors’ impacts—the only metal able to penetrate the coarse flesh of the gigantic creatures.

You will play a band of Veinreapers fighting for the greatest share of Cosmic Ores. The outfit that mines the most ores will rise as the strongest power within Astralevia, taking control of the nation and winning the game.

Summary

Players will take turns placing Veinreapers in Kill Formations against Colossi on the game board while collecting Metal Shards and forging the special Pickaxe that their warriors are equipped with. Each Colossus can only be killed and mined by Veinreapers placed in a specific Kill Formation. The number of Veinreapers engaged against a Colossus and the properties of your warriors’ equipped Pickax determine how many Cosmic Ores you mine from each Colossus. The game ends when all Veinreapers have been placed and the player who mines the most Cosmic Ores based on these placements wins the game.

name: Synergy: A Business Strategy Game
description:
Synergy is a four player business strategy board game designed to mirror real life business industries with billions of possible game play scenarios to create a unique experience for every game.

The setup for Synergy involves the players taking on the roles of new venture capitalists, traveling the world to start and develop new businesses in 16 different industries. Every business’s worth and location in Synergy are randomly assigned based on game play, which allows every game to be different. During the game, players will have the chance to acquire businesses, improve their net incomes, and build up the value of their businesses. Each player’s goal during the game is to finish their career with the highest net worth, which factors in the termination value of the player's businesses and the assets they have acquired over their careers.

Unique dice mechanisms are used to determine player movement and the net incomes of the acquired businesses and action cards are used to create significant shifts in the business landscape. Synergy allows a wide range of business strategies to be applied in a entertaining business simulation game. Each game of Synergy requires the player to assess the business landscape laid out during game play and make reactive adjustments to their strategy, just as they might in the real life business world. To add an extra layer of depth, the game is playable with two separate sets of rules - a Standard Version, for most players, and a Pro Version, for more experienced players who want a greater challenge.
mechanics: Modular Board, Paper-and-Pencil, Roll / Spin and Move, Simulation

name: Battle For New Providence
description:
The event takes place in 1690, the golden period of the "piracy” and describes the pirates attempt to save New Providence by the English navy sent to conquer it.

The game is created on the analogy of the so called "board game" which must be larger and have more complex rules. It is designed for two to four players but with a little effort it can be played individually. This will need the player to make moves alternately on both sides. This way he can try and clarify the various constructions and tactical maneuvers.

The game is built of two interrelated parts. In one you will be admiral of the navy. On one side are the English ships that need to transport military units in order to to take over New Providence. On the other side is the pirate fleet trying to stop them.
If the British army is successfully transferred to the island it will have to face the pirate band's to repel their attacks and conquer in time three forts that have strategic importance for the conquest of the island
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Area Movement, Player Elimination

name: Mr. Bean's superschräges Party-Spiel
description:
From the back of the box (translated from German):

Hello! My name is Bean, Mr. Bean. I have the honor to present to you my unique unique, completely crazy and super oblique party game.

Since it is drawn (if one may call the Doodle above) and circumscribed (what a nice word for chatter) demonstrated and with hands and feet (one wild Gehampel, I tell you) that the laugh lines shake and spill over the bags.

And sometimes I dip itself on and bring even more fun and entertainment (... well, Mr. Bean actually rather creates THE TOTAL CHAOS !! The Red.).

So, take heart! Get into the bean-iest game of all time. Funnier it may not be ...

name: Wort für Wort
description:
From the rules sheet in the game:

How to play
All Letter Tablets are separated, placed face down and shuffled. The Black Tablets are separated and placed face up. Each player takes five Letter Tablets and places them on a Letter Rack, hidden from the opponents. Divide the Black Tablets between all players.

Players in turn each place a Black Tablet on the Playboard leaving at least on square (including diagonally) between all the Black Tablets. Play continues until all Black Tablets have been placed or cannot be placed. The first player must now try to place a complete word anywhere on the board ensuring that it fits between two Black Tablets. If the player is unable to do this a single Letter Tablet is placed anywhere on the board. The player replaces any Tablet used.
Play continues around the Tablet until all the Letter Tablets have been used.

Scoring
Players score either when they place a complete word on the Playboard or when they place Tablet(s) which complete a partly made word. In either case the player scores one point for each Letter Tablet in the completed word.

name: Denken mit Lego
description:
From the back of the box (translated):

Fun games of logic and set theory.

This game will make fun for all because of its many easy and difficult tasks. Here LEGO bricks can not be used as building blocks, but as a sign of thought content. Even children aged 4 to 5 years old want to learn thinking.

Learning to think in the game. For children, gaming is the appropriate learning situation. That's why games are suggested in the book, whose "rules" trigger thought processes:
The player discover Commons and Differents, draw conclusions, identify and apply rules, develop winning strategies, learn to calculate the probability of chance and the like. All this is amusing and fun, just by playing. Also competing games are in there ... and a portion hidden and open mathematics. The game manual is, however, completely without technical terms. IT is - written for amateurs and still gives parents, kindergarten teachers and teachers' knowledge of logical and mathematical relationships and thus the background knowledge that facilitates the development of suitable game situations, which in turn develop and support basic skills for thinking of the children.

User Summary:
There are different "boards" included (paper with geometric structures printed on them)
Instead of the figures, stacks of 2 to 3 LEGO bricks are used. There are multiple games which can be played on these boards or without a board only with the bricks.
Included is a 96 pages book full with different games for the material included, and hints for which age and school grade they are adequate.
Some examples for the games:
"Nine mans mills" rule
A pachisi game with changing blocking rules
A logical rule guessing game: stacks of 3 colored bricks. Which rule is matching for all. e.g. exact 1 white brick in each stack.

name: Mini-Worldcup
description:
Description taken from the back of the box:

Each player has to use one petter. The attack begins from the center. Each player has in turn with his opponent one unchecked kick in order to make a goal. The ball has to be beaten from the point where it comes to a stop. It can be kicked into the goal directly or by rebounding from the borders.

name: Vasa Regalis: The Card Game
description:
Vasa Regalis is a card game version of Vasa Regalis: The Maiden Voyage.

Players are shipyard leaders responsible for the building of the Vasa Ship. At the same time, you want to keep as much material as possible to yourself but beware, if the ship sinks you may get the blame.

The victory conditions are determined by the sum of all players' actions. If players add a lot to the ship, it will succeed but it is the player placing LEAST on the ship that will win. If, on the other hand, players add little to the ship, it will fail and the player placing MOST on the ship will win.

The players start with cards representing goods at different values. Each turn, they may choose to place cards on the ship, inspect cards placed on the ship or replace own cards placed on the ship. When all four parts of the ships have been completed, the game ends and the ship is launched.

The challenge of Vasa Regalis is to correctly guess how much the other players add to the ship.

The unique mechanism of Vasa Regalis is the ambiguous victory conditions. The players can analyze the piles and draw conclusions but never be sure how to win. Should they add as much to a part as possible or as little as possible? They will not know the answer until the ship is launched but then it is too late to do anything about it.

name: Turn of Time
description:
You play a Lord of a Season, bringing seasonal changes to the world. As time goes by, one season replaces another in seasonal order; Spring is followed by Summer, Summer by Fall and Fall by Winter. However, you want to turn the time your way to have your season dominating the world.

When all your season tiles have been played to the game board or you have a majority of season tiles in one area, your season dominates the world.

The players take turn to play season tiles to one of six hexagonal areas, each of which has six season slots. The six season slots are arranged in a circle where each slot is adjacent to two other slots. The six areas are also arranged in a circle where each area is adjacent to two other areas.

Within an area, season tiles must be placed in seasonal order. Between areas, season tiles must be similar. If they are not, the later season will replace the earlier (e.g. Spring will replace Winter).

Besides placing season tiles, a player may turn one area clockwise so that new seasons end up adjacent to each other, resulting in one replacing the other. To really twist the time, a player may turn all areas counter-clockwise, resulting in several seasons replacing each other. However, since this turn is twisted, earlier seasons will replace later (e.g. Winter will replace Spring).

Once a season is banished from an area, it may not easily return, so the players will gradually increase their local dominance until a global winner emerges. To win Turn of Time, you must find the turns that brings most of your seasons to the board while blocking your opponents' opportunities to replace your seasons.

The unique mechanism of Turn of Time is the so called circular relation between the players where A is stronger than B, B is stronger than C etc. This mechanism, in combination with the revolving game areas, opens up in-numerous strategical paths. Should you accept being banished from one area to expand in another? Should you place your seasons so that they can attack easily or so that they are difficult to attack? Will the benefits of turning one or several areas outweigh the benefits other players may receive? Will you even be able to foresee all turns in the game if all areas are turned? You must find the answer yourself!

name: Air Traffic Madness
description: Air Traffic Madness is a game for 2 to 5 people where players compete to land as many planes as possible. Each plane will score a variable number of victory points plus bonuses depending on how challenging a runway you land it on. Each player secretly chooses three orders cards to issue to their planes, two direct orders and one general order. Then players take turns revealing their orders and moving their planes. The player who lands the planes that are worth the most VPs wins. Beware, there are events that occur every other round plus bonus cards that players can earn which will change the course of the game. Each player also has a few planes worth zero VPs which could be damaging to you if they crash into your high valued planes. Can you navigated the hectic air space and be crowned the king of the air traffic control? Are you ready for Air Traffic Madness?
mechanics: Area Movement, Hand Management, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Wallet Warriors Wilderness
description:
They’re brave, adventurous & ready to explore!
Step out of the dungeon and into the light of the endless wilderness! Face deadly new monsters, defeat insidious new traps and discover incredible new treasures! This expansion set for Wallet Warriors gives you new encounter charts, new scenarios and a new challenge: random Events! Plus, with 24 new map cards to explore, the adventure can go on forever. More markers, figures and dice make the set a must have for die-hard adventurers! So get ready to brave the mountains, swamps, oceans and forests of the Wallet Warriors Wilderness!

With a simple roll of the die your adventurers (such as thief, druid or elf) move through the randomly created wilderness and discover either a monster, trap or treasure! If your level and roll is high enough, or if your abilities are good enough, you can beat the adversaries and continue on to succeed in your quest of finding gold, rescuing the princess or just exploring the entire map!

name: Odysseus: Winds of Fate
description: Odysseus took an epic voyage from Troy to Ithaca. You play as the Fates, who observe Odysseus on his voyage... Not entirely interested in whether he makes it home safe or not, you will bet on the outcome of Odysseus' journey and each of his adventures, and then use your influence with the gods to make sure your bets pay off.
mechanics: Betting and Bluffing, Hand Management, Set Collection

name: Flags of Valour: Pacific Campaign
description:
Flags of Valour is a toolkit system for war game enhancement. This particular release is Set 2, and deals with the Japanese and American forces of the Pacific.

FOV is a set of modules that extend the use of any counter based war game so that you can add both the often under-utilized practice of “Fog of War” OR that of higher level Intelligence Gathering and Logistics to virtually any simulation game. The game tool is also used to represent hidden assets such as Ammunition Supply, Fuel, and other factors common to any higher level logistic advantages gained via logistical planning. It is in fact this "Level Over" that FOV uses to bring new strategies and tactics to most war games without changing the underlying game rules. The level of added realism this tool set provides is rarely found in conjunction with any other current game publication.

What the Flags of Valour systems all do is give players of wargames a way to remove most of your counters from the board at the start of any game, and replace them with national hidden placement counters. Meantime you have a hidden area where normal game counters are kept on LUC (Logistical Unit Cards) until enemy recon or proximity force the regular unit pieces to be placed on the board and revealed. This allows war games to start with a form of hidden movement and place that is traditionally thought of as “double blind” play. Except in this case you can do the double-blind with only one central board (unlike the awkward and messy way that most double blind games take up a lot of room and require two copies of a board or a game).

Depending on the particular FOV release, some provide for additional hidden rules such as Strongpoints, Air Strikes, Guerrilla activity, Supply Lines, and more. Add on rules are completely optional, and are left to the discretionary use of the players using the system.

Each FOV release comes with 2-6 nation state counters. There are releases for many different eras available, but primarily the counter sets cover WW2 and Modern use. There are also the “125” series of FOV releases for use with Miniatures games. Those use larger placement counters and much larger LUC (Logistical Unit Cards) on which to place miniatures hidden off the board.
categories: Abstract Strategy, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Modern Warfare, World War II

name: Flags of Valour: Blitzkrieg
description:
Flags of Valour is a toolkit system for war game enhancement. This particular release is Set 3, and deals with counters for the units of the Blitzkrieg years - namely France, Belgium, Netherlands, Poland and Norway.

FOV is a set of modules that extend the use of any counter based war game so that you can add both the often under-utilized practice of “Fog of War” OR that of higher level Intelligence Gathering and Logistics to virtually any simulation game. The game tool is also is used to represent hidden assets such as Ammunition Supply, Fuel, and other factors common to any Operational level command of your troops on a typical battlefield. It is in fact this Operational over-level that FOV uses to bring new strategies and tactics to most war games. The level of added realism this tool set provides is rarely found in conjunction with any other current game publication.

What the Flags of Valour systems all do is give players of wargames a way to remove most of your counters from the board at the start of any game, and replace them with national hidden placement counters. Meantime you have a hidden area where normal game counters are kept on LUC (Logistical Unit Cards) until enemy recon or proximity force the regular unit pieces to be placed on the board and revealed. This allows war games to start with a form of hidden movement and place that is traditionally thought of as “double blind” play. Except in this case you can do the double-blind with only one central board (unlike the awkward and messy way that most double blind games take up a lot of room and require two copies of a board or a game).

Depending on the particular FOV release, some provide for additional hidden rules such as Strongpoints, Air Strikes, Guerilla activity, Supply Lines, and more. Add on rules are completely optional, and are left to the discretionary use of the players using the system.

Each FOV release comes with 2-6 nation state counters. There are releases for many different eras available, but primarily the counter sets cover WW2 and Modern use. There are also the “125” series of FOV releases for use with Miniatures games. Those use larger placement counters and much larger LUC (Logistical Unit Cards) on which to place miniatures hidden off the board.
categories: Abstract Strategy, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Modern Warfare, World War II
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Area Movement, Hexagon Grid, Simulation

name: Cosplay: The Game
description:
In COSPLAY: The Game, two to four players compete against each other to try to become a Cosplay Superstar. Using a variety of cards and events, players gather flair for their costumes, then compete in tournaments to advance their rank. The first player to achieve "Superstar" status wins the game.

A game built from the ground up by cosplayers for cosplayers, you'll recognize many in-game items inspired by and making fun of tropes from your favorite cosplay fandoms. Each player chooses a fandom (video games, anime & TV, steampunk or super heroes) and then works to gather flair for their cosplay before the competition. Flair items range from the ordinary (a "dinosaur egg" or a "steampunk gauntlet") to the outlandish (like the "companion sphere" or the "ridiculous oversized hat").

Easy to learn and play and incredibly portable, it's a perfect game to play when you're stuck in a hotel, at the airport or otherwise looking to have some fun. It's a clever take on the cosplay/convention experience, in playing card form.
categories: Card Game, Humor, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Video Game Theme
mechanics: Hand Management, Push Your Luck, Set Collection

name: Disney Fairies: Fly and Go Seek Game
description:
Disney Fairies: Fly and Go Seek Game is a princess themed memory game.

Object: to fly around the house collecting Treasure Triangles. At the end of the game, the player with the most Treasure Triangles is the winner!

Set Up
1) Decide on four locations around your house to place Treasure Triangles (for example, the kitchen, bedroom, dining room, entry way). These are the places you'll "fly" to!
2) In each location, place six Treasure Triangles as shown. (Wedges meet to form a hexagon). It does not matter which sides are face-up.
3) Everyone sits in a central location.
4) Put all the square Cards inside the bag.
5) Have the sand timer handy.

The player with the next birthday goes first!

On Your Turn:
Reach in the bag and, without looking, pull out a Card. Follow the instructions below based on what kind of Card you pulled:

Picture Card


If you pulled a Picture Card, look at the items on both sides of the Card. Choose one of the sides to place face-up in the center of all the players. Now it's the next player's turn.

Moon Card


If you pulled a Moon Card, place it off to the side to begin creating a picture of a full moon. If the fourth Moon Card is pulled and the picture of the full moon is complete, the game is over (see Ending the Game section below). Otherwise it's the next player's turn.

"Fly and Go Seek" Card


If you pulled a "Fly and Go Seek" Card, follow the directions below:
1) Take a look at ALL the face-up Picture Cards. Try to remember the items on them, but leave them where they are. (Note: if there are no face-up Picture Cards then your turn is over because there are no items to seek, and now it's the next players' turn.)
2) Flip the sand timer over and go!
3) Hurry to the Treasure Triangles around your house. If you see items from face-up Picture Cards on any Treasure Triangles take those Treasure Triangles, take those Treasure Triangles with you.
4) When the sand timer runs out, another player should let you know. Immediately come back with any Treasure Triangles you have collected.
5) Compare the Treasure Triangles you have collected to the face-up Picture Cards. Place each treasure Triangle you have collected that matches a Picture Card in your own scoring pile. Set the matching Picture Cards out of the game.
6) If you collected a Treasure Trinagle that does not have a matching face-up Picture Card, put the Treasure Triangle back and your next turn is skipped. Now it's the next player's turn.

Ending the Game
When the fourth Moon Card is pulled from thebag and the picture of the full moon is complete, the game is over. Players count up the Treasure Triangles they have collected. The player with the most Treasure Triangles wins!

name: The New World: A Colonial 4x Game
description:
The year is 1600. You've been appointed Governor of a small struggling settlement in the New World with instructions to explore and settle these new lands for the Glory of your King and country. However, your nation is not alone in these new lands. For your colony to survive you will have to bargain with the powerful Native tribes and deal with your Nation's enemies who also have settlements here.

The New World is a 4x tile laying game for 3-4 players set in Colonial North America. Players can either play the French, English, Spanish, or Dutch with the goal of building your empire and collecting Glory for the Crown. Since each game will feature random exploration by laying tiles, no two games will play the same.
You will win this game by exploring, building your settlements by claiming and purchasing land from the Native tribes, and eventually coming into conflict with your country's competitors in the New World. All this will build up Glory Points in the name of your King.

The game plays quickly with each player on their turn having a choice of a single action from either:

1) Exploring: Paying to launch expeditions to place tiles, claim/purchase land, and placing influence markers (representing traders and missionaries) in the hopes of Allying and trading with the tribes.
2) Economic Turn: Building up your Colony by creating new settlements, building Forts, repairing settlements that were damaged, maintaining troops, and collecting wealth from taxes and trade
3) War: Eventually you will have to deal with the enemies of your King here in the The New World. If you choose this action this is where you will raise your armies and send them across the frontiers. Be forewarned though. War is not cheap. You will need a strong economy to wage successful war. There is only so much that the Crown can do to help your fledgling colony.

The New World is buffed by a large Event deck that brings out the historical events of the times. It also serves to pace the game by having Events that represent the Peace Treaties that ended the big European Wars that spilled over into North America. Whenever a Peace Event is drawn, there will be a few turns of truce and Glory Points will be awarded based on the number of Settlements, the number of claimed territories, and by your Alliances with the Native Tribes. Once 3 Peace Events are drawn the game will be over.

This game is rather unique by it's Exploration/Tile laying mechanic, it's quick engaging turns, it's streamlined easy rules including a nice combat resolution, the ability to bounce back from a disaster, and and a unique, more historical, representation of the native tribes.
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Area Movement, Modular Board

name: The Lion King: Simba's Pride – Pride Rock Pairs
description:
Help pair up each of the animal types and Simba and Nala's daughter, Kiara, with Kovu the male cub she has fallen in love with.

The game is a variant on a memory match game, but the pairs are a male and female of a species and the male and female tiles are different shapes, that form a heart shape when matched.

The game also comes with a display area that is set up to the side of the play area where all the matched pairs are placed.

name: Mura Korogashi: France
description: This expansion for the game Mura Korogashi includes 11 new types of tiles that allow players to build a village in France.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Modular Board, Tile Placement

name: Mura Korogashi: Spain
description: This expansion for the game Mura Korogashi includes 11 new types of tiles that allow players to build a village in Spain.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Modular Board, Tile Placement

name: American Monster Hunters
description:
Hunt it. Find it. Slay it.

In the small towns and lonely highways of America, monsters lurk in the shadows, stalking and terrorizing innocent victims. You are a small team of monster hunters — average citizens that know the truth about the creatures of the night. You are on the hunt for an unknown monster. Can you identify the monster and track it to its lair before it claims its victims and disappears once more into the shadows?

American Monster Hunters is a cooperative card game set in a mythic rural America haunted by monsters. You and your friends collect clue cards and work together to reveal the identity of the monster, determined by random mystery cards at the start of each game. Each turn, you must decide whether to protect victims, prepare for the coming fight against the monster, or progress the hunt. Variable powers, ever-increasing risk, and fast-paced turns make for a tense, exciting, and unique game each time.

Print-and-play coming soon!

name: The Ultimate Beer Game
description:
The Ultimate Beer Game is a board game in which players travel their pawn across the board, encountering “obstacles” in a battle to get to the finish line first. Obstacles include things like The Bridge of Doom, Potato's House, The Beach, etc. Along the way, players will be instructed to drink, pick cards, and answer slightly humorous questionnaires out loud to the other players. It is designed to be interactive, socially and physically, within the players.

This game boasts 8 pawns in a range of colors, and one blue die, all neatly packed into a drawstring canvas bag to withstand the tests of time longer than the typical heat-sealed plastic bag most games include. This means your pawns and die won’t be rolling around aimlessly inside the box once you open them. (Our pawns are made in the U.S.A. They are eco-friendly, filled with postindustrial wood trim.)

This game includes 52 Beer Cards and Bong Cards collectively, which are packed into a playing card box. Our cards are water-resistant and should clean off pretty easily if wet.

This game can be played while easily substituting alcohol with any beverage, using alcohol is an OPTIONAL part of this game.
This game is meant to be played by those of legal drinking age, and is prohibited to be played by any minor. Some tiles include curse words, obscene ideas, and some offensive language and graphics in general.
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Battle Fear: Monster Dice
description:
Battle Fear flips the dice game on its head. Roll miniature figures to determine actions like attacking, healing, powering up, and drawing a card. The luck of the dice and strategy of playing cards makes this game perfect for kids and adults. A game so portable you can Battle Fear anywhere at anytime.
Set-up:
1. Players choose two Monster Dice. Each Monster has a Combat Card and a set of Backup Cards.

2. Place the power tracker on the left and the health tracker on the right of the Combat Card. Each Monster starts with a specific power and health level.

3. Shuffle the two sets of Backup Cards together and place them face down.

How to Play:
1. Both players roll their Monster Dice. Depending on how they land have actions that are described on the Combat Card.

2. Head - Attack any enemy -2 health.
Feet - Heal self or ally +1 health.
Face - Power up self or ally +1 power.
Back - Draw a Backup Card.
Sides - No Action

3. Backup cards can be played when a player has enough power to use on that action.

4. Adjust the power and health for each Monster on the Combat Card. Repeat.

Victory is achieved when both enemy Monsters have fallen to 0 health.

name: Imperium Chronicles: In Harm's Way Tactics – March of the Metal Horde
description:
March of the Metal Horde is the first expansion for the In Harm's Way Tactics wargame. During each game, players take the role of unique character classes, each with their own set of special abilities and weapons. The game includes at least three ways to play, including quick skirmishes, missions, or a campaign. Solo play is also supported.

March of the Metal Horde (MotMH) expands the original game with additional character classes, abilities, weapons, and enemies to fight.

(Disclaimer: Not affiliated with the In Harm's Way line of RPGs published by Flying Mice Games.)
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Paper-and-Pencil

name: Servas-Miniaturspiel
description:
